column2: To My Readers.
column3: To My Readers.

column2: It's no use; no use at all. The children won't let me stop telling tales of the Land of Oz. I know lots of other stories, and I hope to tell them, some time or another;
column3: It's no use; no use at all. The children won't let me stop telling tales of the Land of Oz. I know lots of other stories, and I hope to tell them, some time or another;

column2: but just now my loving tyrants won't allow me.
column3: but just now my loving tyrants won't allow me.

column2: They cry: Oz Oz! more about Oz, Mr. Baum! and what can I do but obey their commands?
column3: They cry: Oz Oz! more about Oz, Mr. Baum! and what can I do but obey their commands?

column2: This is Our Book mine and the children's. For they have flooded me with thousands of suggestions in regard to it, and I have honestly tried to adopt as many of these suggestions as could be fitted into one story.
column3: This is Our Book mine and the children's. For they have flooded me with thousands of suggestions in regard to it, and I have honestly tried to adopt as many of these suggestions as could be fitted into one story.

column2: After the wonderful success of Ozma of Oz it is evident that Dorothy has become a firm fixture in these Oz stories. The little ones all love Dorothy,
column3: After the wonderful success of Ozma of Oz it is evident that Dorothy has become a firm fixture in these Oz stories. The little ones all love Dorothy,

column2: and as one of my small friends aptly states:
column3: and as one of my small friends aptly states:

column2: It isn't a real Oz story without her.
column3: It isn't a real Oz story without her.

column2: So here she is again, as sweet and gentle and innocent as ever, I hope, and the heroine of another strange adventure.
column3: So here she is again, as sweet and gentle and innocent as ever, I hope, and the heroine of another strange adventure.

column2: There were many requests from my little correspondents for more about the Wizard. It seems the jolly old fellow made hosts of friends in the first Oz book,
column3: There were many requests from my little correspondents for more about the Wizard. It seems the jolly old fellow made hosts of friends in the first Oz book,

column2: in spite of the fact that he frankly acknowledged himself a humbug.
column3: in spite of the fact that he frankly acknowledged himself a humbug.

column2: The children had heard how he mounted into the sky in a balloon and they were all waiting for him to come down again. So what could I do but tell what happened to the Wizard afterward?
column3: The children had heard how he mounted into the sky in a balloon and they were all waiting for him to come down again. So what could I do but tell what happened to the Wizard afterward?

column2: You will find him in these pages, just the same humbug Wizard as before.
column3: You will find him in these pages, just the same humbug Wizard as before.

column2: There was one thing the children demanded which I found it impossible to do in this present book: they bade me introduce Toto, Dorothy's little black dog,
column3: There was one thing the children demanded which I found it impossible to do in this present book: they bade me introduce Toto, Dorothy's little black dog,

column2: who has many friends among my readers.
column3: who has many friends among my readers.

column2: But you will see, when you begin to read the story, that Toto was in Kansas while Dorothy was in California, and so she had to start on her adventure without him.
column3: But you will see, when you begin to read the story, that Toto was in Kansas while Dorothy was in California, and so she had to start on her adventure without him.

column2: In this book Dorothy had to take her kitten with her instead of her dog; but in the next Oz book, if I am permitted to write one, I intend to tell a good deal about Toto's further history.
column3: In this book Dorothy had to take her kitten with her instead of her dog; but in the next Oz book, if I am permitted to write one, I intend to tell a good deal about Toto's further history.

column2: Princess Ozma, whom I love as much as my readers do, is again introduced in this story, and so are several of our old friends of Oz.
column3: Princess Ozma, whom I love as much as my readers do, is again introduced in this story, and so are several of our old friends of Oz.

column2: You will also become acquainted with Jim the Cab-Horse, the Nine Tiny Piglets, and Eureka, the Kitten. I am sorry the kitten was not as well behaved as she ought to have been;
column3: You will also become acquainted with Jim the Cab-Horse, the Nine Tiny Piglets, and Eureka, the Kitten. I am sorry the kitten was not as well behaved as she ought to have been;

column2: but perhaps she wasn't brought up properly.
column3: but perhaps she wasn't brought up properly.

column2: Dorothy found her, you see, and who her parents were nobody knows.
column3: Dorothy found her, you see, and who her parents were nobody knows.

column2: I believe, my dears, that I am the proudest story-teller that ever lived. Many a time tears of pride and joy have stood in my eyes while I read the tender,
column3: I believe, my dears, that I am the proudest story-teller that ever lived. Many a time tears of pride and joy have stood in my eyes while I read the tender,

column2: loving, appealing letters that came to me in almost every mail from my little readers.
column3: loving, appealing letters that came to me in almost every mail from my little readers.

column2: To have pleased you, to have interested you, to have won your friendship, and perhaps your love, through my stories, is to my mind as great an achievement as to become President of the United States.
column3: To have pleased you, to have interested you, to have won your friendship, and perhaps your love, through my stories, is to my mind as great an achievement as to become President of the United States.

column2: Indeed, I would much rather be your story-teller, under these conditions, than to be the President. So you have helped me to fulfill my life's ambition,
column3: Indeed, I would much rather be your story-teller, under these conditions, than to be the President. So you have helped me to fulfill my life's ambition,

column2: and I am more grateful to you, my dears, than I can express in words.
column3: and I am more grateful to you, my dears, than I can express in words.

column2: I try to answer every letter of my young correspondents; yet sometimes there are so many letters that a little time must pass before you get your answer.
column3: I try to answer every letter of my young correspondents; yet sometimes there are so many letters that a little time must pass before you get your answer.

column2: But be patient, friends, for the answer will surely come, and by writing to me you more than repay me for the pleasant task of preparing these books.
column3: But be patient, friends, for the answer will surely come, and by writing to me you more than repay me for the pleasant task of preparing these books.

column2: Besides, I am proud to acknowledge that the books are partly yours, for your suggestions often guide me in telling the stories,
column3: Besides, I am proud to acknowledge that the books are partly yours, for your suggestions often guide me in telling the stories,

column2: and I am sure they would not be half so good without your clever and thoughtful assistance.
column3: and I am sure they would not be half so good without your clever and thoughtful assistance.

column2: L FRANK BAUM, Coronado, 1908.

column2: The train from 'Frisco was very late. It should have arrived at Hugson's Siding at midnight,
column3: The train from 'Frisco was very late. It should have arrived at Hugson's Siding at midnight,

column2: but it was already five o'clock and the gray dawn was breaking in the east when the little train slowly rumbled up to the open shed that served for the station-house.
column3: but it was already five o'clock and the gray dawn was breaking in the east when the little train slowly rumbled up to the open shed that served for the station-house.

column2: As it came to a stop the conductor called out in a loud voice: Hugson's Siding!
column3: As it came to a stop the conductor called out in a loud voice: Hugson's Siding!

column2: At once a little girl rose from her seat and walked to the door of the car, carrying a wicker suit-case in one hand and a round bird-cage covered up with newspapers in the other,

column2: The reason he was so late was because all through the night there were times when the solid earth shook and trembled under him,

column2: So he moved the cars slowly and with caution.

column2: with its head hanging down almost to the ground.

column3: The buggy seemed almost new, for it had a shiny top and side curtains. Getting around in front, so that she could look inside, the girl saw a boy curled up on the seat, fast asleep.

column2: Is Mr. Hugson your uncle? she asked.

column3: Yes. Uncle Bill Hugson married your Uncle Henry's wife's sister; so we must be second cousins, said the boy, in an amused tone.

column2: I work for Uncle Bill on his ranch, and he pays me six dollars a month and my board.
column3: I work for Uncle Bill on his ranch, and he pays me six dollars a month and my board.

column2: Isn't that a great deal? she asked, doubtfully.
column3: Isn't that a great deal? she asked, doubtfully.

column2: Why, it's a great deal for Uncle Hugson, but not for me. I'm a splendid worker. I work as well as I sleep, he added, with a laugh.
column3: Why, it's a great deal for Uncle Hugson, but not for me. I'm a splendid worker. I work as well as I sleep, he added, with a laugh.

column3: What is your name? said Dorothy, thinking she liked the boy's manner and the cheery tone of his voice.

column3: Not a very pretty one, he answered, as if a little ashamed. My whole name is Zebediah; but folks just call me 'Zeb.' You've been to Australia, haven't you?

column3: Only a day. Tomorrow Uncle Henry and I must start back for Kansas.

column2: But he had no hair at all, and all over his bald head and face and upon the backs of his hands grew sharp thorns like those found on the branches of rose-bushes.
column3: But he had no hair at all, and all over his bald head and face and upon the backs of his hands grew sharp thorns like those found on the branches of rose-bushes.

column2: There was even a thorn upon the tip of his nose and he looked so funny that Dorothy laughed when she saw him.
column3: There was even a thorn upon the tip of his nose and he looked so funny that Dorothy laughed when she saw him.

column2: The Sorcerer, hearing the laugh, looked toward the little girl with cold, cruel eyes, and his glance made her grow sober in an instant.
column3: The Sorcerer, hearing the laugh, looked toward the little girl with cold, cruel eyes, and his glance made her grow sober in an instant.

column2: Why have you dared to intrude your unwelcome persons into the secluded Land of the Mangaboos? he asked, sternly.
column3: Why have you dared to intrude your unwelcome persons into the secluded Land of the Mangaboos? he asked, sternly.

column2: 'Cause we couldn't help it, said Dorothy.
column3: 'Cause we couldn't help it, said Dorothy.

column2: Why did you wickedly and viciously send the Rain of Stones to crack and break our houses? he continued.
column3: Why did you wickedly and viciously send the Rain of Stones to crack and break our houses? he continued.

column2: We didn't, declared the girl.
column3: We didn't, declared the girl.

column2: Prove it! cried the Sorcerer.
column3: Prove it! cried the Sorcerer.

column2: We don't have to prove it, answered Dorothy, indignantly. If you had any sense at all you'd known it was the earthquake.
column3: We don't have to prove it, answered Dorothy, indignantly. If you had any sense at all you'd known it was the earthquake.

column2: We only know that yesterday came a Rain of Stones upon us, which did much damage and injured some of our people. Today came another Rain of Stones,
column3: We only know that yesterday came a Rain of Stones upon us, which did much damage and injured some of our people. Today came another Rain of Stones,

column2: and soon after it you appeared among us.
column3: and soon after it you appeared among us.

column2: By the way, said the man with the star, looking steadily at the Sorcerer, you told us yesterday that there would not be a second Rain of Stones.
column3: By the way, said the man with the star, looking steadily at the Sorcerer, you told us yesterday that there would not be a second Rain of Stones.

column2: Yet one has just occurred that was even worse than the first. What is your sorcery good for if it cannot tell us the truth?
column3: Yet one has just occurred that was even worse than the first. What is your sorcery good for if it cannot tell us the truth?

column2: My sorcery does tell the truth! declared the thorn-covered man. I said there would be but one Rain of Stones. This second one was a Rain of People-and-Horse-and-Buggy.
column3: My sorcery does tell the truth! declared the thorn-covered man. I said there would be but one Rain of Stones. This second one was a Rain of People-and-Horse-and-Buggy.

column2: And some stones came with them.
column3: And some stones came with them.

column2: Will there be any more Rains? asked the man with the star.
column3: Will there be any more Rains? asked the man with the star.

column2: No, my Prince.
column3: No, my Prince.

column2: Neither stones nor people?
column3: Neither stones nor people?

column2: No, my Prince.
column3: No, my Prince.

column2: Are you sure?
column3: Are you sure?

column2: Quite sure, my Prince. My sorcery tells me so.
column3: Quite sure, my Prince. My sorcery tells me so.

column2: Just then a man came running into the hall and addressed the Prince after making a low bow.
column3: Just then a man came running into the hall and addressed the Prince after making a low bow.

column2: More wonders in the air, my Lord, said he.
column3: More wonders in the air, my Lord, said he.

column2: Immediately the Prince and all of his people flocked out of the hall into the street, that they might see what was about to happen.
column3: Immediately the Prince and all of his people flocked out of the hall into the street, that they might see what was about to happen.

column2: Dorothy and Zeb jumped out of the buggy and ran after them, but the Sorcerer remained calmly in his throne.

column2: but was descending slowly through the air so slowly that at first it scarcely seemed to move.
column3: but was descending slowly through the air so slowly that at first it scarcely seemed to move.

column3: The throng stood still and waited. It was all they could do, for to go away and leave that strange sight was impossible; nor could they hurry its fall in any way.

column3: with Eureka curled up asleep on the seat of the buggy.

column3: Gradually the balloon grew bigger, which was proof that it was settling down upon the Land of the Mangaboos. Dorothy was surprised to find how patient the people were,

column2: for her own little heart was beating rapidly with excitement.
column3: for her own little heart was beating rapidly with excitement.

column2: A balloon meant to her some other arrival from the surface of the earth, and she hoped it would be some one able to assist her and Zeb out of their difficulties.
column3: A balloon meant to her some other arrival from the surface of the earth, and she hoped it would be some one able to assist her and Zeb out of their difficulties.

column2: In an hour the balloon had come near enough for her to see a basket suspended below it; in two hours she could see a head looking over the side of the basket;
column3: In an hour the balloon had come near enough for her to see a basket suspended below it; in two hours she could see a head looking over the side of the basket;

column2: in three hours the big balloon settled slowly into the great square in which they stood and came to rest on the glass pavement.
column3: in three hours the big balloon settled slowly into the great square in which they stood and came to rest on the glass pavement.

column2: Then a little man jumped out of the basket, took off his tall hat, and bowed very gracefully to the crowd of Mangaboos around him.
column3: Then a little man jumped out of the basket, took off his tall hat, and bowed very gracefully to the crowd of Mangaboos around him.

column2: He was quite an old little man and his head was long and entirely bald.
column3: He was quite an old little man and his head was long and entirely bald.

column2: Why, cried Dorothy, in amazement, it's Oz!
column3: Why, cried Dorothy, in amazement, it's Oz!

column2: The little man looked toward her and seemed as much surprised as she was. But he smiled and bowed as he answered:
column3: The little man looked toward her and seemed as much surprised as she was. But he smiled and bowed as he answered:

column2: Yes, my dear; I am Oz, the Great and Terrible. Eh? And you are little Dorothy, from Kansas. I remember you very well.
column3: Yes, my dear; I am Oz, the Great and Terrible. Eh? And you are little Dorothy, from Kansas. I remember you very well.

column2: Who did you say it was? whispered Zeb to the girl.
column3: Who did you say it was? whispered Zeb to the girl.

column2: It's the wonderful Wizard of Oz. Haven't you heard of him?
column3: It's the wonderful Wizard of Oz. Haven't you heard of him?

column2: Just then the man with the star came and stood before the Wizard.
column3: Just then the man with the star came and stood before the Wizard.

column2: Sir, said he, why are you here, in the Land of the Mangaboos?
column3: Sir, said he, why are you here, in the Land of the Mangaboos?

column2: Didn't know what land it was, my son, returned the other, with a pleasant smile; and, to be honest, I didn't mean to visit you when I started out.
column3: Didn't know what land it was, my son, returned the other, with a pleasant smile; and, to be honest, I didn't mean to visit you when I started out.

column2: I live on top of the earth, your honor, which is far better than living inside it;
column3: I live on top of the earth, your honor, which is far better than living inside it;

column2: but yesterday I went up in a balloon, and when I came down I fell into a big crack in the earth, caused by an earthquake.
column3: but yesterday I went up in a balloon, and when I came down I fell into a big crack in the earth, caused by an earthquake.

column2: I had let so much gas out of my balloon that I could not rise again, and in a few minutes the earth closed over my head. So I continued to descend until I reached this place,
column3: I had let so much gas out of my balloon that I could not rise again, and in a few minutes the earth closed over my head. So I continued to descend until I reached this place,

column2: and if you will show me a way to get out of it, I'll go with pleasure.
column3: and if you will show me a way to get out of it, I'll go with pleasure.

column2: Sorry to have troubled you; but it couldn't be helped.
column3: Sorry to have troubled you; but it couldn't be helped.

column2: The Prince had listened with attention. Said he:
column3: The Prince had listened with attention. Said he:

column2: This child, who is from the crust of the earth, like yourself, called you a Wizard. Is not a Wizard something like a Sorcerer?
column3: This child, who is from the crust of the earth, like yourself, called you a Wizard. Is not a Wizard something like a Sorcerer?

column2: It's better, replied Oz, promptly. One Wizard is worth three Sorcerers.
column3: It's better, replied Oz, promptly. One Wizard is worth three Sorcerers.

column2: Ah, you shall prove that, said the Prince. We Mangaboos have, at the present time, one of the most wonderful Sorcerers that ever was picked from a bush;
column3: Ah, you shall prove that, said the Prince. We Mangaboos have, at the present time, one of the most wonderful Sorcerers that ever was picked from a bush;

column2: but he sometimes makes mistakes. Do you ever make mistakes?
column3: but he sometimes makes mistakes. Do you ever make mistakes?

column2: Never! declared the Wizard, boldly.
column3: Never! declared the Wizard, boldly.

column2: Oh, Oz! said Dorothy; you made a lot of mistakes when you were in the marvelous Land of Oz.
column3: Oh, Oz! said Dorothy; you made a lot of mistakes when you were in the marvelous Land of Oz.

column2: Nonsense! said the little man, turning red although just then a ray of violet sunlight was on his round face.
column3: Nonsense! said the little man, turning red although just then a ray of violet sunlight was on his round face.

column2: Come with me, said the Prince to him. I wish to meet our Sorcerer.
column3: Come with me, said the Prince to him. I wish to meet our Sorcerer.

column2: The Wizard did not like this invitation, but he could not refuse to accept it. So he followed the Prince into the great domed hall, and Dorothy and Zeb came after them,
column3: The Wizard did not like this invitation, but he could not refuse to accept it. So he followed the Prince into the great domed hall, and Dorothy and Zeb came after them,

column2: while the throng of people trooped in also.
column3: while the throng of people trooped in also.

column2: There sat the thorny Sorcerer in his chair of state, and when the Wizard saw him he began to laugh, uttering comical little chuckles.
column3: There sat the thorny Sorcerer in his chair of state, and when the Wizard saw him he began to laugh, uttering comical little chuckles.

column2: What an absurd creature! he exclaimed.
column3: What an absurd creature! he exclaimed.

column2: He may look absurd, said the Prince, in his quiet voice; but he is an excellent Sorcerer. The only fault I find with him is that he is so often wrong.
column3: He may look absurd, said the Prince, in his quiet voice; but he is an excellent Sorcerer. The only fault I find with him is that he is so often wrong.

column2: I am never wrong, answered the Sorcerer.
column3: I am never wrong, answered the Sorcerer.

column2: Only a short time ago you told me there would be no more Rain of Stones or of People, said the Prince.
column3: Only a short time ago you told me there would be no more Rain of Stones or of People, said the Prince.

column2: Well, what then?
column3: Well, what then?

column2: Here is another person descended from the air to prove you were wrong.
column3: Here is another person descended from the air to prove you were wrong.

column2: One person cannot be called 'people,' said the Sorcerer. If two should come out of the sky you might with justice say I was wrong; but unless more than this one appears I will hold that I was right.
column3: One person cannot be called 'people,' said the Sorcerer. If two should come out of the sky you might with justice say I was wrong; but unless more than this one appears I will hold that I was right.

column2: Very clever, said the Wizard, nodding his head as if pleased. I am delighted to find humbugs inside the earth, just the same as on top of it.
column3: Very clever, said the Wizard, nodding his head as if pleased. I am delighted to find humbugs inside the earth, just the same as on top of it.

column2: Were you ever with a circus, brother?
column3: Were you ever with a circus, brother?

column2: No, said the Sorcerer.
column3: No, said the Sorcerer.

column2: You ought to join one, declared the little man seriously. I belong to Bailum & Barney's Great Consolidated Shows three rings in one tent and a menagerie on the side.
column3: You ought to join one, declared the little man seriously. I belong to Bailum  Barney's Great Consolidated Shows three rings in one tent and a menagerie on the side.

column2: It's a fine aggregation, I assure you.
column3: It's a fine aggregation, I assure you.

column2: What do you do? asked the Sorcerer.
column3: What do you do? asked the Sorcerer.

column2: I go up in a balloon, usually, to draw the crowds to the circus. But I've just had the bad luck to come out of the sky, skip the solid earth, and land lower down than I intended.
column3: I go up in a balloon, usually, to draw the crowds to the circus. But I've just had the bad luck to come out of the sky, skip the solid earth, and land lower down than I intended.

column2: But never mind. It isn't everybody who gets a chance to see your Land of the Gabazoos.
column3: But never mind. It isn't everybody who gets a chance to see your Land of the Gabazoos.

column2: Mangaboos, said the Sorcerer, correcting him. If you are a Wizard you ought to be able to call people by their right names.
column3: Mangaboos, said the Sorcerer, correcting him. If you are a Wizard you ought to be able to call people by their right names.

column2: Oh, I'm a Wizard; you may be sure of that. Just as good a Wizard as you are a Sorcerer.
column3: Oh, I'm a Wizard; you may be sure of that. Just as good a Wizard as you are a Sorcerer.

column2: That remains to be seen, said the other.
column3: That remains to be seen, said the other.

column2: If you are able to prove that you are better, said the Prince to the little man, I will make you the Chief Wizard of this domain.
column3: If you are able to prove that you are better, said the Prince to the little man, I will make you the Chief Wizard of this domain.

column2: Otherwise What will happen otherwise? asked the Wizard.
column3: Otherwise What will happen otherwise? asked the Wizard.

column2: I will stop you from living and forbid you to be planted, returned the Prince.
column3: I will stop you from living and forbid you to be planted, returned the Prince.

column2: That does not sound especially pleasant, said the little man, looking at the one with the star uneasily. But never mind. I'll beat Old Prickly, all right.

column3: My name is Gwig, said the Sorcerer, turning his heartless, cruel eyes upon his rival. Let me see you equal the sorcery I am about to perform.

column2: He waved a thorny hand and at once the tinkling of bells was heard, playing sweet music. Yet, look where she would, Dorothy could discover no bells at all in the great glass hall.

column2: The Mangaboo people listened, but showed no great interest. It was one of the things Gwig usually did to prove he was a sorcerer.
column3: The Mangaboo people listened, but showed no great interest. It was one of the things Gwig usually did to prove he was a sorcerer.

column2: Now was the Wizard's turn, so he smiled upon the assemblage and asked:
column3: Now was the Wizard's turn, so he smiled upon the assemblage and asked:

column2: Will somebody kindly loan me a hat?
column3: Will somebody kindly loan me a hat?

column2: No one did, because the Mangaboos did not wear hats, and Zeb had lost his, somehow, in his flight through the air.
column3: No one did, because the Mangaboos did not wear hats, and Zeb had lost his, somehow, in his flight through the air.

column2: Ahem! said the Wizard, will somebody please loan me a handkerchief?
column3: Ahem! said the Wizard, will somebody please loan me a handkerchief?

column2: But they had no handkerchiefs, either.
column3: But they had no handkerchiefs, either.

column2: Very good, remarked the Wizard. I'll use my own hat, if you please.
column3: Very good, remarked the Wizard. I'll use my own hat, if you please.

column2: Now, good people, observe me carefully. You see, there is nothing up my sleeve and nothing concealed about my person. Also, my hat is quite empty.
column3: Now, good people, observe me carefully. You see, there is nothing up my sleeve and nothing concealed about my person. Also, my hat is quite empty.

column2: He took off his hat and held it upside down, shaking it briskly.
column3: He took off his hat and held it upside down, shaking it briskly.

column2: Let me see it, said the Sorcerer.
column3: Let me see it, said the Sorcerer.

column2: He took the hat and examined it carefully, returning it afterward to the Wizard.
column3: He took the hat and examined it carefully, returning it afterward to the Wizard.

column2: Now, said the little man, I will create something out of nothing.
column3: Now, said the little man, I will create something out of nothing.

column2: He placed the hat upon the glass floor, made a pass with his hand, and then removed the hat, displaying a little white piglet no bigger than a mouse,
column3: He placed the hat upon the glass floor, made a pass with his hand, and then removed the hat, displaying a little white piglet no bigger than a mouse,

column2: which began to run around here and there and to grunt and squeal in a tiny, shrill voice.
column3: which began to run around here and there and to grunt and squeal in a tiny, shrill voice.

column2: The people watched it intently, for they had never seen a pig before, big or little. The Wizard reached out, caught the wee creature in his hand,

column2: and holding its head between one thumb and finger and its tail between the other thumb and finger he pulled it apart, each of the two parts becoming a whole and separate piglet in an instant.
column3: and holding its head between one thumb and finger and its tail between the other thumb and finger he pulled it apart, each of the two parts becoming a whole and separate piglet in an instant.

column2: He placed one upon the floor, so that it could run around, and pulled apart the other, making three piglets in all; and then one of these was pulled apart, making four piglets.
column3: He placed one upon the floor, so that it could run around, and pulled apart the other, making three piglets in all; and then one of these was pulled apart, making four piglets.

column2: The Wizard continued this surprising performance until nine tiny piglets were running about at his feet, all squealing and grunting in a very comical way.
column3: The Wizard continued this surprising performance until nine tiny piglets were running about at his feet, all squealing and grunting in a very comical way.

column2: Now, said the Wizard of Oz, having created something from nothing, I will make something nothing again.
column3: Now, said the Wizard of Oz, having created something from nothing, I will make something nothing again.

column3: With this he caught up two of the piglets and pushed them together, so that the two were one. Then he caught up another piglet and pushed it into the first, where it disappeared.

column2: And so, one by one, the nine tiny piglets were pushed together until but a single one of the creatures remained. This the Wizard placed underneath his hat and made a mystic sign above it.
column3: And so, one by one, the nine tiny piglets were pushed together until but a single one of the creatures remained. This the Wizard placed underneath his hat and made a mystic sign above it.

column2: The little man gave a bow to the silent throng that had watched him, and then the Prince said, in his cold, calm voice:
column3: The little man gave a bow to the silent throng that had watched him, and then the Prince said, in his cold, calm voice:

column2: You are indeed a wonderful Wizard, and your powers are greater than those of my Sorcerer.
column3: You are indeed a wonderful Wizard, and your powers are greater than those of my Sorcerer.

column2: He will not be a wonderful Wizard long, remarked Gwig.
column3: He will not be a wonderful Wizard long, remarked Gwig.

column2: Why not? enquired the Wizard.
column3: Why not? enquired the Wizard.

column2: Because I am going to stop your breath, was the reply. I perceive that you are curiously constructed, and that if you cannot breathe you cannot keep alive.
column3: Because I am going to stop your breath, was the reply. I perceive that you are curiously constructed, and that if you cannot breathe you cannot keep alive.

column2: The little man looked troubled.
column3: The little man looked troubled.

column2: How long will it take you to stop my breath? he asked.
column3: How long will it take you to stop my breath? he asked.

column2: About five minutes. I'm going to begin now. Watch me carefully.
column3: About five minutes. I'm going to begin now. Watch me carefully.

column2: He began making queer signs and passes toward the Wizard; but the little man did not watch him long. Instead, he drew a leathern case from his pocket and took from it several sharp knives,

column2: which he joined together, one after another, until they made a long sword.

column2: By the time he had attached a handle to this sword he was having much trouble to breathe, as the charm of the Sorcerer was beginning to take effect.
column3: By the time he had attached a handle to this sword he was having much trouble to breathe, as the charm of the Sorcerer was beginning to take effect.

column2: So the Wizard lost no more time, but leaping forward he raised the sharp sword, whirled it once or twice around his head, and then gave a mighty stroke that cut the body of the Sorcerer exactly in two.
column3: So the Wizard lost no more time, but leaping forward he raised the sharp sword, whirled it once or twice around his head, and then gave a mighty stroke that cut the body of the Sorcerer exactly in two.

column2: Dorothy screamed and expected to see a terrible sight; but as the two halves of the Sorcerer fell apart on the floor she saw that he had no bones or blood inside of him at all,
column3: Dorothy screamed and expected to see a terrible sight; but as the two halves of the Sorcerer fell apart on the floor she saw that he had no bones or blood inside of him at all,

column2: and that the place where he was cut looked much like a sliced turnip or potato.
column3: and that the place where he was cut looked much like a sliced turnip or potato.

column2: Why, he's vegetable! cried the Wizard, astonished.
column3: Why, he's vegetable! cried the Wizard, astonished.

column3: Of course, said the Prince. We are all vegetable, in this country.

column2: Are you not vegetable, also?
column3: Are you not vegetable, also?

column3: Will your Sorcerer die?

column2: Certainly, sir. He is really dead now, and will wither very quickly.
column3: Certainly, sir. He is really dead now, and will wither very quickly.

column2: So we must plant him at once, that other Sorcerers may grow upon his bush, continued the Prince.
column3: So we must plant him at once, that other Sorcerers may grow upon his bush, continued the Prince.

column3: What do you mean by that? asked the little Wizard, greatly puzzled.

column3: Who built these lovely bridges? asked the little girl.

column2: No one built them, answered the man with the star. They grow.
column3: No one built them, answered the man with the star. They grow.

column2: That's queer, said she. Did the glass houses in your city grow, too?
column3: That's queer, said she. Did the glass houses in your city grow, too?

column2: Of course, he replied. But it took a good many years for them to grow as large and fine as they are now. That is why we are so angry when a Rain of Stones comes to break our towers and crack our roofs.
column3: Of course, he replied. But it took a good many years for them to grow as large and fine as they are now. That is why we are so angry when a Rain of Stones comes to break our towers and crack our roofs.

column2: Can't you mend them? she enquired.
column3: Can't you mend them? she enquired.

column2: No; but they will grow together again, in time, and we must wait until they do.
column3: No; but they will grow together again, in time, and we must wait until they do.

column2: They first passed through many beautiful gardens of flowers, which grew nearest the city; but Dorothy could hardly tell what kind of flowers they were,
column3: They first passed through many beautiful gardens of flowers, which grew nearest the city; but Dorothy could hardly tell what kind of flowers they were,

column2: because the colors were constantly changing under the shifting lights of the six suns.
column3: because the colors were constantly changing under the shifting lights of the six suns.

column2: A flower would be pink one second, white the next, then blue or yellow; and it was the same way when they came to the plants, which had broad leaves and grew close to the ground.
column3: A flower would be pink one second, white the next, then blue or yellow; and it was the same way when they came to the plants, which had broad leaves and grew close to the ground.

column2: When they passed over a field of grass Jim immediately stretched down his head and began to nibble.
column3: When they passed over a field of grass Jim immediately stretched down his head and began to nibble.

column2: A nice country this is, he grumbled, where a respectable horse has to eat pink grass!
column3: A nice country this is, he grumbled, where a respectable horse has to eat pink grass!

column2: It's violet, said the Wizard, who was in the buggy.
column3: It's violet, said the Wizard, who was in the buggy.

column2: Now it's blue, complained the horse. As a matter of fact, I'm eating rainbow grass.
column3: Now it's blue, complained the horse. As a matter of fact, I'm eating rainbow grass.

column2: How does it taste? asked the Wizard.
column3: How does it taste? asked the Wizard.

column2: Not bad at all, said Jim. If they give me plenty of it I'll not complain about its color.
column3: Not bad at all, said Jim. If they give me plenty of it I'll not complain about its color.

column2: By this time the party had reached a freshly plowed field, and the Prince said to Dorothy:
column3: By this time the party had reached a freshly plowed field, and the Prince said to Dorothy:

column2: This is our planting-ground.
column3: This is our planting-ground.

column2: Several Mangaboos came forward with glass spades and dug a hole in the ground. Then they put the two halves of the Sorcerer into it and covered him up.
column3: Several Mangaboos came forward with glass spades and dug a hole in the ground. Then they put the two halves of the Sorcerer into it and covered him up.

column2: After that other people brought water from a brook and sprinkled the earth.
column3: After that other people brought water from a brook and sprinkled the earth.

column2: He will sprout very soon, said the Prince, and grow into a large bush, from which we shall in time be able to pick several very good sorcerers.
column3: He will sprout very soon, said the Prince, and grow into a large bush, from which we shall in time be able to pick several very good sorcerers.

column2: Do all your people grow on bushes? asked the boy.
column3: Do all your people grow on bushes? asked the boy.

column2: Certainly, was the reply. Do not all people grow upon bushes where you came from, on the outside of the earth?
column3: Certainly, was the reply. Do not all people grow upon bushes where you came from, on the outside of the earth?

column2: Not that I ever hear of.
column3: Not that I ever hear of.

column2: How strange! But if you will come with me to one of our folk gardens I will show you the way we grow in the Land of the Mangaboos.
column3: How strange! But if you will come with me to one of our folk gardens I will show you the way we grow in the Land of the Mangaboos.

column2: It appeared that these odd people, while they were able to walk through the air with ease, usually moved upon the ground in the ordinary way.
column3: It appeared that these odd people, while they were able to walk through the air with ease, usually moved upon the ground in the ordinary way.

column2: There were no stairs in their houses, because they did not need them, but on a level surface they generally walked just as we do.
column3: There were no stairs in their houses, because they did not need them, but on a level surface they generally walked just as we do.

column2: The little party of strangers now followed the Prince across a few more of the glass bridges and along several paths until they came to a garden enclosed by a high hedge.
column3: The little party of strangers now followed the Prince across a few more of the glass bridges and along several paths until they came to a garden enclosed by a high hedge.

column2: Jim had refused to leave the field of grass, where he was engaged in busily eating; so the Wizard got out of the buggy and joined Zeb and Dorothy,
column3: Jim had refused to leave the field of grass, where he was engaged in busily eating; so the Wizard got out of the buggy and joined Zeb and Dorothy,

column2: and the kitten followed demurely at their heels.
column3: and the kitten followed demurely at their heels.

column2: Inside the hedge they came upon row after row of large and handsome plants with broad leaves gracefully curving until their points nearly reached the ground.
column3: Inside the hedge they came upon row after row of large and handsome plants with broad leaves gracefully curving until their points nearly reached the ground.

column2: In the center of each plant grew a daintily dressed Mangaboo, for the clothing of all these creatures grew upon them and was attached to their bodies.
column3: In the center of each plant grew a daintily dressed Mangaboo, for the clothing of all these creatures grew upon them and was attached to their bodies.

column2: The growing Mangaboos were of all sizes, from the blossom that had just turned into a wee baby to the full-grown and almost ripe man or woman.
column3: The growing Mangaboos were of all sizes, from the blossom that had just turned into a wee baby to the full-grown and almost ripe man or woman.

column2: On some of the bushes might be seen a bud, a blossom, a baby, a half-grown person and a ripe one; but even those ready to pluck were motionless and silent, as if devoid of life.
column3: On some of the bushes might be seen a bud, a blossom, a baby, a half-grown person and a ripe one; but even those ready to pluck were motionless and silent, as if devoid of life.

column2: This sight explained to Dorothy why she had seen no children among the Mangaboos, a thing she had until now been unable to account for.
column3: This sight explained to Dorothy why she had seen no children among the Mangaboos, a thing she had until now been unable to account for.

column2: Our people do not acquire their real life until they leave their bushes, said the Prince. You will notice they are all attached to the plants by the soles of their feet,
column3: Our people do not acquire their real life until they leave their bushes, said the Prince. You will notice they are all attached to the plants by the soles of their feet,

column2: and when they are quite ripe they are easily separated from the stems and at once attain the powers of motion and speech.
column3: and when they are quite ripe they are easily separated from the stems and at once attain the powers of motion and speech.

column2: So while they grow they cannot be said to really live, and they must be picked before they can become good citizens.
column3: So while they grow they cannot be said to really live, and they must be picked before they can become good citizens.

column2: How long do you live, after you are picked? asked Dorothy.
column3: How long do you live, after you are picked? asked Dorothy.

column2: That depends upon the care we take of ourselves, he replied. If we keep cool and moist, and meet with no accidents, we often live for five years.
column3: That depends upon the care we take of ourselves, he replied. If we keep cool and moist, and meet with no accidents, we often live for five years.

column2: I've been picked over six years, but our family is known to be especially long lived.
column3: I've been picked over six years, but our family is known to be especially long lived.

column2: Do you eat? asked the boy.
column3: Do you eat? asked the boy.

column2: Eat! No, indeed. We are quite solid inside our bodies, and have no need to eat, any more than does a potato.
column3: Eat! No, indeed. We are quite solid inside our bodies, and have no need to eat, any more than does a potato.

column2: But the potatoes sometimes sprout, said Zeb.
column3: But the potatoes sometimes sprout, said Zeb.

column2: And sometimes we do, answered the Prince; but that is considered a great misfortune, for then we must be planted at once.
column3: And sometimes we do, answered the Prince; but that is considered a great misfortune, for then we must be planted at once.

column2: Where did you grow? asked the Wizard.
column3: Where did you grow? asked the Wizard.

column2: I will show you, was the reply. Step this way, please.
column3: I will show you, was the reply. Step this way, please.

column2: He led them within another but smaller circle of hedge, where grew one large and beautiful bush.
column3: He led them within another but smaller circle of hedge, where grew one large and beautiful bush.

column2: This, said he, is the Royal Bush of the Mangaboos. All of our Princes and Rulers have grown upon this one bush from time immemorial.
column3: This, said he, is the Royal Bush of the Mangaboos. All of our Princes and Rulers have grown upon this one bush from time immemorial.

column2: They stood before it in silent admiration.
column3: They stood before it in silent admiration.

column2: On the central stalk stood poised the figure of a girl so exquisitely formed and colored and so lovely in the expression of her delicate features that Dorothy thought she had never seen so sweet and adorable a creature in all her life.
column3: On the central stalk stood poised the figure of a girl so exquisitely formed and colored and so lovely in the expression of her delicate features that Dorothy thought she had never seen so sweet and adorable a creature in all her life.

column2: The maiden's gown was soft as satin and fell about her in ample folds, while dainty lace-like traceries trimmed the bodice and sleeves.
column3: The maiden's gown was soft as satin and fell about her in ample folds, while dainty lace-like traceries trimmed the bodice and sleeves.

column2: Her flesh was fine and smooth as polished ivory, and her poise expressed both dignity and grace.
column3: Her flesh was fine and smooth as polished ivory, and her poise expressed both dignity and grace.

column2: Who is this? asked the Wizard, curiously.
column3: Who is this? asked the Wizard, curiously.

column2: The Prince had been staring hard at the girl on the bush. Now he answered, with a touch of uneasiness in his cold tones:
column3: The Prince had been staring hard at the girl on the bush. Now he answered, with a touch of uneasiness in his cold tones:

column2: She is the Ruler destined to be my successor, for she is a Royal Princess. When she becomes fully ripe I must abandon the sovereignty of the Mangaboos to her.
column3: She is the Ruler destined to be my successor, for she is a Royal Princess. When she becomes fully ripe I must abandon the sovereignty of the Mangaboos to her.

column2: Isn't she ripe now? asked Dorothy.
column3: Isn't she ripe now? asked Dorothy.

column2: He hesitated.
column3: He hesitated.

column2: Not quite, said he, finally. It will be several days before she needs to be picked, or at least that is my judgment. I am in no hurry to resign my office and be planted, you may be sure.
column3: Not quite, said he, finally. It will be several days before she needs to be picked, or at least that is my judgment. I am in no hurry to resign my office and be planted, you may be sure.

column2: Probably not, declared the Wizard, nodding.
column3: Probably not, declared the Wizard, nodding.

column2: This is one of the most unpleasant things about our vegetable lives, continued the Prince, with a sigh, that while we are in our full prime we must give way to another,
column3: This is one of the most unpleasant things about our vegetable lives, continued the Prince, with a sigh, that while we are in our full prime we must give way to another,

column2: and be covered up in the ground to sprout and grow and give birth to other people.
column3: and be covered up in the ground to sprout and grow and give birth to other people.

column2: I'm sure the Princess is ready to be picked, asserted Dorothy, gazing hard at the beautiful girl on the bush. She's as perfect as she can be.
column3: I'm sure the Princess is ready to be picked, asserted Dorothy, gazing hard at the beautiful girl on the bush. She's as perfect as she can be.

column2: Never mind, answered the Prince, hastily, she will be all right for a few days longer, and it is best for me to rule until I can dispose of you strangers,
column3: Never mind, answered the Prince, hastily, she will be all right for a few days longer, and it is best for me to rule until I can dispose of you strangers,

column2: who have come to our land uninvited and must be attended to at once.
column3: who have come to our land uninvited and must be attended to at once.

column2: What are you going to do with us? asked Zeb.
column3: What are you going to do with us? asked Zeb.

column2: That is a matter I have not quite decided upon, was the reply. I think I shall keep this Wizard until a new Sorcerer is ready to pick, for he seems quite skillful and may be of use to us.
column3: That is a matter I have not quite decided upon, was the reply. I think I shall keep this Wizard until a new Sorcerer is ready to pick, for he seems quite skillful and may be of use to us.

column2: But the rest of you must be destroyed in some way, and you cannot be planted, because I do not wish horses and cats and meat people growing all over our country.
column3: But the rest of you must be destroyed in some way, and you cannot be planted, because I do not wish horses and cats and meat people growing all over our country.

column2: You needn't worry, said Dorothy. We wouldn't grow under ground, I'm sure.
column3: You needn't worry, said Dorothy. We wouldn't grow under ground, I'm sure.

column2: But why destroy my friends? asked the little Wizard. Why not let them live?
column3: But why destroy my friends? asked the little Wizard. Why not let them live?

column2: They do not belong here, returned the Prince. They have no right to be inside the earth at all.
column3: They do not belong here, returned the Prince. They have no right to be inside the earth at all.

column2: We didn't ask to come down here; we fell, said Dorothy.
column3: We didn't ask to come down here; we fell, said Dorothy.

column2: That is no excuse, declared the Prince, coldly.
column3: That is no excuse, declared the Prince, coldly.

column2: The children looked at each other in perplexity, and the Wizard sighed.
column3: The children looked at each other in perplexity, and the Wizard sighed.

column2: Eureka rubbed her paw on her face and said in her soft, purring voice:
column3: Eureka rubbed her paw on her face and said in her soft, purring voice:

column2: He won't need to destroy ME, for if I don't get something to eat pretty soon I shall starve to death, and so save him the trouble.
column3: He won't need to destroy ME, for if I don't get something to eat pretty soon I shall starve to death, and so save him the trouble.

column2: If he planted you, he might grow some cat-tails, suggested the Wizard.
column3: If he planted you, he might grow some cat-tails, suggested the Wizard.

column2: Oh, Eureka! perhaps we can find you some milk-weeds to eat, said the boy.
column3: Oh, Eureka! perhaps we can find you some milk-weeds to eat, said the boy.

column2: Phoo! snarled the kitten; I wouldn't touch the nasty things!
column3: Phoo! snarled the kitten; I wouldn't touch the nasty things!

column2: You don't need milk, Eureka, remarked Dorothy; you are big enough now to eat any kind of food.
column3: You don't need milk, Eureka, remarked Dorothy; you are big enough now to eat any kind of food.

column2: If I can get it, added Eureka.
column3: If I can get it, added Eureka.

column2: I'm hungry myself, said Zeb. But I noticed some strawberries growing in one of the gardens, and some melons in another place.
column3: I'm hungry myself, said Zeb. But I noticed some strawberries growing in one of the gardens, and some melons in another place.

column2: These people don't eat such things, so perhaps on our way back they will let us get them.
column3: These people don't eat such things, so perhaps on our way back they will let us get them.

column2: Never mind your hunger, interrupted the Prince. I shall order you destroyed in a few minutes, so you will have no need to ruin our pretty melon vines and berry bushes.
column3: Never mind your hunger, interrupted the Prince. I shall order you destroyed in a few minutes, so you will have no need to ruin our pretty melon vines and berry bushes.

column2: Follow me, please, to meet your doom.
column3: Follow me, please, to meet your doom.

column2: End of chapter 4.
column3: End of chapter four.

column2: Dorothy and the Wizard in Oz L Frank Baum. Chapter 5. Dorothy Picks the Princess.
column3: Dorothy and the Wizard in Oz L Frank Baum. Chapter five. Dorothy Picks the Princess.

column2: The words of the cold and moist vegetable Prince were not very comforting, and as he spoke them he turned away and left the enclosure.
column3: The words of the cold and moist vegetable Prince were not very comforting, and as he spoke them he turned away and left the enclosure.

column2: The children, feeling sad and despondent, were about to follow him when the Wizard touched Dorothy softly on her shoulder.
column3: The children, feeling sad and despondent, were about to follow him when the Wizard touched Dorothy softly on her shoulder.

column2: Wait! he whispered.
column3: Wait! he whispered.

column2: What for? asked the girl.
column3: What for? asked the girl.

column2: Suppose we pick the Royal Princess, said the Wizard. I'm quite sure she's ripe, and as soon as she comes to life she will be the Ruler, and may treat us better than that heartless Prince intends to.
column3: Suppose we pick the Royal Princess, said the Wizard. I'm quite sure she's ripe, and as soon as she comes to life she will be the Ruler, and may treat us better than that heartless Prince intends to.

column2: All right! exclaimed Dorothy, eagerly. Let's pick her while we have the chance, before the man with the star comes back.
column3: All right! exclaimed Dorothy, eagerly. Let's pick her while we have the chance, before the man with the star comes back.

column2: So together they leaned over the great bush and each of them seized one hand of the lovely Princess.
column3: So together they leaned over the great bush and each of them seized one hand of the lovely Princess.

column2: Pull! cried Dorothy, and as they did so the royal lady leaned toward them and the stems snapped and separated from her feet.
column3: Pull! cried Dorothy, and as they did so the royal lady leaned toward them and the stems snapped and separated from her feet.

column2: She was not at all heavy, so the Wizard and Dorothy managed to lift her gently to the ground.
column3: She was not at all heavy, so the Wizard and Dorothy managed to lift her gently to the ground.

column2: The beautiful creature passed her hands over her eyes an instant, tucked in a stray lock of hair that had become disarranged, and after a look around the garden made those present a gracious bow and said,
column3: The beautiful creature passed her hands over her eyes an instant, tucked in a stray lock of hair that had become disarranged, and after a look around the garden made those present a gracious bow and said,

column2: in a sweet but even toned voice:
column3: in a sweet but even toned voice:

column2: I thank you very much.
column3: I thank you very much.

column2: We salute your Royal Highness! cried the Wizard, kneeling and kissing her hand.
column3: We salute your Royal Highness! cried the Wizard, kneeling and kissing her hand.

column2: Just then the voice of the Prince was heard calling upon them to hasten, and a moment later he returned to the enclosure, followed by a number of his people.
column3: Just then the voice of the Prince was heard calling upon them to hasten, and a moment later he returned to the enclosure, followed by a number of his people.

column2: Instantly the Princess turned and faced him, and when he saw that she was picked the Prince stood still and began to tremble.
column3: Instantly the Princess turned and faced him, and when he saw that she was picked the Prince stood still and began to tremble.

column2: Sir, said the Royal Lady, with much dignity, you have wronged me greatly, and would have wronged me still more had not these strangers come to my rescue.
column3: Sir, said the Royal Lady, with much dignity, you have wronged me greatly, and would have wronged me still more had not these strangers come to my rescue.

column2: I have been ready for picking all the past week, but because you were selfish and desired to continue your unlawful rule, you left me to stand silent upon my bush.
column3: I have been ready for picking all the past week, but because you were selfish and desired to continue your unlawful rule, you left me to stand silent upon my bush.

column2: I did not know that you were ripe, answered the Prince, in a low voice.
column3: I did not know that you were ripe, answered the Prince, in a low voice.

column2: Give me the Star of Royalty! she commanded.
column3: Give me the Star of Royalty! she commanded.

column2: Slowly he took the shining star from his own brow and placed it upon that of the Princess. Then all the people bowed low to her, and the Prince turned and walked away alone.
column3: Slowly he took the shining star from his own brow and placed it upon that of the Princess. Then all the people bowed low to her, and the Prince turned and walked away alone.

column2: What became of him afterward our friends never knew.
column3: What became of him afterward our friends never knew.

column2: The people of Mangaboo now formed themselves into a procession and marched toward the glass city to escort their new ruler to her palace and to perform those ceremonies proper to the occasion.
column3: The people of Mangaboo now formed themselves into a procession and marched toward the glass city to escort their new ruler to her palace and to perform those ceremonies proper to the occasion.

column2: But while the people in the procession walked upon the ground the Princess walked in the air just above their heads, to show that she was a superior being and more exalted than her subjects.
column3: But while the people in the procession walked upon the ground the Princess walked in the air just above their heads, to show that she was a superior being and more exalted than her subjects.

column2: No one now seemed to pay any attention to the strangers, so Dorothy and Zeb and the Wizard let the train pass on and then wandered by themselves into the vegetable gardens.
column3: No one now seemed to pay any attention to the strangers, so Dorothy and Zeb and the Wizard let the train pass on and then wandered by themselves into the vegetable gardens.

column2: They did not bother to cross the bridges over the brooks, but when they came to a stream they stepped high and walked in the air to the other side.
column3: They did not bother to cross the bridges over the brooks, but when they came to a stream they stepped high and walked in the air to the other side.

column2: This was a very interesting experience to them, and Dorothy said:
column3: This was a very interesting experience to them, and Dorothy said:

column2: I wonder why it is that we can walk so easily in the air.
column3: I wonder why it is that we can walk so easily in the air.

column2: Perhaps, answered the Wizard, it is because we are close to the center of the earth, where the attraction of gravitation is very slight.
column3: Perhaps, answered the Wizard, it is because we are close to the center of the earth, where the attraction of gravitation is very slight.

column2: But I've noticed that many queer things happen in fairy countries.
column3: But I've noticed that many queer things happen in fairy countries.

column2: Is this a fairy country? asked the boy.
column3: Is this a fairy country? asked the boy.

column2: Of course it is, returned Dorothy promptly. Only a fairy country could have veg'table people; and only in a fairy country could Eureka and Jim talk as we do.
column3: Of course it is, returned Dorothy promptly. Only a fairy country could have veg'table people; and only in a fairy country could Eureka and Jim talk as we do.

column2: That's true, said Zeb, thoughtfully.
column3: That's true, said Zeb, thoughtfully.

column2: In the vegetable gardens they found the strawberries and melons, and several other unknown but delicious fruits, of which they ate heartily.
column3: In the vegetable gardens they found the strawberries and melons, and several other unknown but delicious fruits, of which they ate heartily.

column2: But the kitten bothered them constantly by demanding milk or meat, and called the Wizard names because he could not bring her a dish of milk by means of his magical arts.
column3: But the kitten bothered them constantly by demanding milk or meat, and called the Wizard names because he could not bring her a dish of milk by means of his magical arts.

column2: As they sat upon the grass watching Jim, who was still busily eating, Eureka said:
column3: As they sat upon the grass watching Jim, who was still busily eating, Eureka said:

column2: I don't believe you are a Wizard at all!
column3: I don't believe you are a Wizard at all!

column2: No, answered the little man, you are quite right. In the strict sense of the word I am not a Wizard, but only a humbug.
column3: No, answered the little man, you are quite right. In the strict sense of the word I am not a Wizard, but only a humbug.

column2: The Wizard of Oz has always been a humbug, agreed Dorothy. I've known him for a long time.
column3: The Wizard of Oz has always been a humbug, agreed Dorothy. I've known him for a long time.

column2: If that is so, said the boy, how could he do that wonderful trick with the nine tiny piglets?
column3: If that is so, said the boy, how could he do that wonderful trick with the nine tiny piglets?

column2: Don't know, said Dorothy, but it must have been humbug.
column3: Don't know, said Dorothy, but it must have been humbug.

column2: Very true, declared the Wizard, nodding at her. It was necessary to deceive that ugly Sorcerer and the Prince, as well as their stupid people;
column3: Very true, declared the Wizard, nodding at her. It was necessary to deceive that ugly Sorcerer and the Prince, as well as their stupid people;

column2: but I don't mind telling you, who are my friends, that the thing was only a trick.
column3: but I don't mind telling you, who are my friends, that the thing was only a trick.

column2: But I saw the little pigs with my own eyes! exclaimed Zeb.
column3: But I saw the little pigs with my own eyes! exclaimed Zeb.

column2: So did I, purred the kitten.
column3: So did I, purred the kitten.

column2: To be sure, answered the Wizard. You saw them because they were there. They are in my inside pocket now. But the pulling of them apart and pushing them together again was only a sleight-of-hand trick.
column3: To be sure, answered the Wizard. You saw them because they were there. They are in my inside pocket now. But the pulling of them apart and pushing them together again was only a sleight-of-hand trick.

column2: Let's see the pigs, said Eureka, eagerly.
column3: Let's see the pigs, said Eureka, eagerly.

column2: The little man felt carefully in his pocket and pulled out the tiny piglets, setting them upon the grass one by one, where they ran around and nibbled the tender blades.
column3: The little man felt carefully in his pocket and pulled out the tiny piglets, setting them upon the grass one by one, where they ran around and nibbled the tender blades.

column2: They're hungry, too, he said.
column3: They're hungry, too, he said.

column2: Oh, what cunning things! cried Dorothy, catching up one and petting it.
column3: Oh, what cunning things! cried Dorothy, catching up one and petting it.

column2: Be careful! said the piglet, with a squeal, you're squeezing me!
column3: Be careful! said the piglet, with a squeal, you're squeezing me!

column2: Dear me! murmured the Wizard, looking at his pets in astonishment.
column3: Dear me! murmured the Wizard, looking at his pets in astonishment.

column2: They can actually talk!
column3: They can actually talk!

column2: May I eat one of them? asked the kitten, in a pleading voice. I'm awfully hungry.
column3: May I eat one of them? asked the kitten, in a pleading voice. I'm awfully hungry.

column2: Why, Eureka, said Dorothy, reproachfully, what a cruel question! It would be dreadful to eat these dear little things.
column3: Why, Eureka, said Dorothy, reproachfully, what a cruel question! It would be dreadful to eat these dear little things.

column2: I should say so! grunted another of the piglets, looking uneasily at the kitten; cats are cruel things.
column3: I should say so! grunted another of the piglets, looking uneasily at the kitten; cats are cruel things.

column2: I'm not cruel, replied the kitten, yawning. I'm just hungry.
column3: I'm not cruel, replied the kitten, yawning. I'm just hungry.

column2: You cannot eat my piglets, even if you are starving, declared the little man, in a stern voice. They are the only things I have to prove I'm a wizard.
column3: You cannot eat my piglets, even if you are starving, declared the little man, in a stern voice. They are the only things I have to prove I'm a wizard.

column2: How did they happen to be so little? asked Dorothy. I never saw such small pigs before.
column3: How did they happen to be so little? asked Dorothy. I never saw such small pigs before.

column2: They are from the Island of Teenty-Weent, said the Wizard, where everything is small because it's a small island. A sailor brought them to Los Angeles and I gave him nine tickets to the circus for them.

column2: I suppose the vegetable folk were always afraid to enter this cavern because it is dark; but we have our lanterns to light the way, so I propose that we start out and discover where this tunnel in the mountain leads to.

column2: It was all laid out into lovely lawns and gardens, with pebble paths leading through them and groves of beautiful and stately trees dotting the landscape here and there.

column2: There were orchards, too, bearing luscious fruits that are all unknown in our world. Alluring brooks of crystal water flowed sparkling between their flower-strewn banks,

column2: One was that it was lighted from some unseen source; for no sun or moon was in the arched blue sky, although every object was flooded with a clear and perfect light.

column3: Isn't it fine? cried Dorothy, in a joyous voice, as she sprang out of the buggy and let Eureka run frolicking over the velvety grass.

column3: Yes, indeed! answered Zeb. We were lucky to get away from those dreadful vegetable people.

column2: Can't imagine, my dear, he replied.
column3: Can't imagine, my dear, he replied.

column2: the piglets racing and gambolling beside them and Jim pausing at every step for another mouthful of grass.

column2: The fruit was so daintily colored and so fragrant, and looked so appetizing and delicious that Dorothy stopped and exclaimed:
column3: The fruit was so daintily colored and so fragrant, and looked so appetizing and delicious that Dorothy stopped and exclaimed:

column2: What is it, do you s'pose?
column3: What is it, do you s'pose?

column3: The piglets had smelled the fruit quickly, and before the girl could reach out her hand to pluck it every one of the nine tiny ones had rushed in and commenced to devour it with great eagerness.

column3: It's good, anyway, said Zeb, or those little rascals wouldn't have gobbled it up so greedily.

column2: Where are they? asked Dorothy, in astonishment.
column3: Where are they? asked Dorothy, in astonishment.

column2: They all looked around, but the piglets had disappeared.
column3: They all looked around, but the piglets had disappeared.

column2: Dear me! cried the Wizard; they must have run away. But I didn't see them go; did you?
column3: Dear me! cried the Wizard; they must have run away. But I didn't see them go; did you?

column2: No! replied the boy and the girl, together.
column3: No! replied the boy and the girl, together.

column2: Here, piggy, piggy, piggy! called their master, anxiously.
column3: Here, piggy, piggy, piggy! called their master, anxiously.

column3: Several squeals and grunts were instantly heard at his feet, but the Wizard could not discover a single piglet.

column2: Where are you? he asked.
column3: Where are you? he asked.

column2: Why, right beside you, spoke a tiny voice. Can't you see us?
column3: Why, right beside you, spoke a tiny voice. Can't you see us?

column2: No, answered the little man, in a puzzled tone.
column3: No, answered the little man, in a puzzled tone.

column2: We can see you, said another of the piglets.
column3: We can see you, said another of the piglets.

column2: The Wizard stooped down and put out his hand, and at once felt the small fat body of one of his pets. He picked it up, but could not see what he held.
column3: The Wizard stooped down and put out his hand, and at once felt the small fat body of one of his pets. He picked it up, but could not see what he held.

column2: It is very strange, said he, soberly. The piglets have become invisible, in some curious way.
column3: It is very strange, said he, soberly. The piglets have become invisible, in some curious way.

column2: I'll bet it's because they ate that peach! cried the kitten.
column3: I'll bet it's because they ate that peach! cried the kitten.

column3: It wasn't a peach, Eureka, said Dorothy. I only hope it wasn't poison.

column2: It was fine, Dorothy, called one of the piglets.
column3: It was fine, Dorothy, called one of the piglets.

column2: We'll eat all we can find of them, said another.
column3: We'll eat all we can find of them, said another.

column3: But WE mus'n't eat them, the Wizard warned the children, or we too may become invisible, and lose each other. If we come across another of the strange fruit we must avoid it.

column2: The travellers now resumed their walk toward the cottage, which they presently reached. It was a pretty place, with vines growing thickly over the broad front porch.
column3: The travellers now resumed their walk toward the cottage, which they presently reached. It was a pretty place, with vines growing thickly over the broad front porch.

column2: The door stood open and a table was set in the front room, with four chairs drawn up to it. On the table were plates, knives and forks, and dishes of bread, meat and fruits.
column3: The door stood open and a table was set in the front room, with four chairs drawn up to it. On the table were plates, knives and forks, and dishes of bread, meat and fruits.

column2: The meat was smoking hot and the knives and forks were performing strange antics and jumping here and there in quite a puzzling way.
column3: The meat was smoking hot and the knives and forks were performing strange antics and jumping here and there in quite a puzzling way.

column2: But not a single person appeared to be in the room.
column3: But not a single person appeared to be in the room.

column2: How funny! exclaimed Dorothy, who with Zeb and the Wizard now stood in the doorway.
column3: How funny! exclaimed Dorothy, who with Zeb and the Wizard now stood in the doorway.

column3: A peal of merry laughter answered her, and the knives and forks fell to the plates with a clatter. One of the chairs pushed back from the table,

column2: and this was so astonishing and mysterious that Dorothy was almost tempted to run away in fright.
column3: and this was so astonishing and mysterious that Dorothy was almost tempted to run away in fright.

column2: Here are strangers, mama! cried the shrill and childish voice of some unseen person.
column3: Here are strangers, mama! cried the shrill and childish voice of some unseen person.

column2: So I see, my dear, answered another voice, soft and womanly.
column3: So I see, my dear, answered another voice, soft and womanly.

column2: What do you want? demanded a third voice, in a stern, gruff accent.
column3: What do you want? demanded a third voice, in a stern, gruff accent.

column2: Well, well! said the Wizard; are there really people in this room?
column3: Well, well! said the Wizard; are there really people in this room?

column3: Of course, replied the man's voice.

column2: And pardon me for the foolish question but, are you all invisible?
column3: And pardon me for the foolish question but, are you all invisible?

column2: Surely, the woman answered, repeating her low, rippling laughter.
column3: Surely, the woman answered, repeating her low, rippling laughter.

column2: Are you surprised that you are unable to see the people of Voe?
column3: Are you surprised that you are unable to see the people of Voe?

column2: Why, yes, stammered the Wizard. All the people I have ever met before were very plain to see.
column3: Why, yes, stammered the Wizard. All the people I have ever met before were very plain to see.

column2: Where do you come from, then? asked the woman, in a curious tone.
column3: Where do you come from, then? asked the woman, in a curious tone.

column2: We belong upon the face of the earth, explained the Wizard, but recently, during an earthquake, we fell down a crack and landed in the Country of the Mangaboos.
column3: We belong upon the face of the earth, explained the Wizard, but recently, during an earthquake, we fell down a crack and landed in the Country of the Mangaboos.

column2: Dreadful creatures! exclaimed the woman's voice. I've heard of them.
column3: Dreadful creatures! exclaimed the woman's voice. I've heard of them.

column2: They walled us up in a mountain, continued the Wizard; but we found there was a tunnel through to this side, so we came here. It is a beautiful place. What do you call it?
column3: They walled us up in a mountain, continued the Wizard; but we found there was a tunnel through to this side, so we came here. It is a beautiful place. What do you call it?

column2: It is the Valley of Voe.
column3: It is the Valley of Voe.

column2: Thank you. We have seen no people since we arrived, so we came to this house to enquire our way.
column3: Thank you. We have seen no people since we arrived, so we came to this house to enquire our way.

column2: Are you hungry? asked the woman's voice.
column3: Are you hungry? asked the woman's voice.

column3: I could eat something, said Dorothy.

column2: But we do not wish to intrude, I assure you, the Wizard hastened to say.
column3: But we do not wish to intrude, I assure you, the Wizard hastened to say.

column2: That's all right, returned the man's voice, more pleasantly than before. You are welcome to what we have.
column3: That's all right, returned the man's voice, more pleasantly than before. You are welcome to what we have.

column2: As he spoke the voice came so near to Zeb that he jumped back in alarm.
column3: As he spoke the voice came so near to Zeb that he jumped back in alarm.

column2: Two childish voices laughed merrily at this action, and Dorothy was sure they were in no danger among such light-hearted folks, even if those folks couldn't be seen.
column3: Two childish voices laughed merrily at this action, and Dorothy was sure they were in no danger among such light-hearted folks, even if those folks couldn't be seen.

column2: What curious animal is that which is eating the grass on my lawn?
column3: What curious animal is that which is eating the grass on my lawn?

column2: enquired the man's voice.
column3: enquired the man's voice.

column2: That's Jim, said the girl. He's a horse.
column3: That's Jim, said the girl. He's a horse.

column2: What is he good for? was the next question.
column3: What is he good for? was the next question.

column2: He draws the buggy you see fastened to him, and we ride in the buggy instead of walking, she explained.
column3: He draws the buggy you see fastened to him, and we ride in the buggy instead of walking, she explained.

column2: Can he fight? asked the man's voice.
column3: Can he fight? asked the man's voice.

column2: No! he can kick pretty hard with his heels, and bite a little; but Jim can't zactly fight, she replied.
column3: No! he can kick pretty hard with his heels, and bite a little; but Jim can't zactly fight, she replied.

column2: Then the bears will get him, said one of the children's voices.
column3: Then the bears will get him, said one of the children's voices.

column2: Bears! exclaimed Dorothy. Are these bears here?
column3: Bears! exclaimed Dorothy. Are these bears here?

column2: That is the one evil of our country, answered the invisible man.
column3: That is the one evil of our country, answered the invisible man.

column2: Many large and fierce bears roam in the Valley of Voe, and when they can catch any of us they eat us up; but as they cannot see us, we seldom get caught.
column3: Many large and fierce bears roam in the Valley of Voe, and when they can catch any of us they eat us up; but as they cannot see us, we seldom get caught.

column2: Are the bears invis'ble, too? asked the girl.
column3: Are the bears invis'ble, too? asked the girl.

column2: Yes; for they eat of the dama-fruit, as we all do, and that keeps them from being seen by any eye, whether human or animal.
column3: Yes; for they eat of the dama-fruit, as we all do, and that keeps them from being seen by any eye, whether human or animal.

column2: Does the dama-fruit grow on a low bush, and look something like a peach? asked the Wizard.
column3: Does the dama-fruit grow on a low bush, and look something like a peach? asked the Wizard.

column2: Yes, was the reply.
column3: Yes, was the reply.

column2: If it makes you invis'ble, why do you eat it? Dorothy enquired.
column3: If it makes you invis'ble, why do you eat it? Dorothy enquired.

column2: For two reasons, my dear, the woman's voice answered. The dama-fruit is the most delicious thing that grows, and when it makes us invisible the bears cannot find us to eat us up.
column3: For two reasons, my dear, the woman's voice answered. The dama-fruit is the most delicious thing that grows, and when it makes us invisible the bears cannot find us to eat us up.

column2: But now, good wanderers, your luncheon is on the table, so please sit down and eat as much as you like.
column3: But now, good wanderers, your luncheon is on the table, so please sit down and eat as much as you like.

column2: End of chapter 8.
column3: End of chapter eight.
