column2: Dorothy and the Wizard in Oz L Frank Baum. Chapter 9. They Fight the Invisible Bears.
column3: Dorothy and the Wizard in Oz L Frank Baum. Chapter nine. They Fight the Invisible Bears.

column2: The strangers took their seats at the table willingly enough, for they were all hungry and the platters were now heaped with good things to eat.
column3: The strangers took their seats at the table willingly enough, for they were all hungry and the platters were now heaped with good things to eat.

column2: In front of each place was a plate bearing one of the delicious dama-fruit, and the perfume that rose from these was so enticing and sweet that they were sorely tempted to eat of them and become invisible.
column3: In front of each place was a plate bearing one of the delicious dama-fruit, and the perfume that rose from these was so enticing and sweet that they were sorely tempted to eat of them and become invisible.

column2: But Dorothy satisfied her hunger with other things, and her companions did likewise, resisting the temptation.
column3: But Dorothy satisfied her hunger with other things, and her companions did likewise, resisting the temptation.

column2: Why do you not eat the damas? asked the woman's voice.
column3: Why do you not eat the damas? asked the woman's voice.

column2: We don't want to get invis'ble, answered the girl.
column3: We don't want to get invis'ble, answered the girl.

column2: But if you remain visible the bears will see you and devour you, said a girlish young voice, that belonged to one of the children.
column3: But if you remain visible the bears will see you and devour you, said a girlish young voice, that belonged to one of the children.

column2: We who live here much prefer to be invisible; for we can still hug and kiss one another, and are quite safe from the bears.
column3: We who live here much prefer to be invisible; for we can still hug and kiss one another, and are quite safe from the bears.

column2: And we do not have to be so particular about our dress, remarked the man.
column3: And we do not have to be so particular about our dress, remarked the man.

column2: And mama can't tell whether my face is dirty or not! added the other childish voice, gleefully.
column3: And mama can't tell whether my face is dirty or not! added the other childish voice, gleefully.

column2: But I make you wash it, every time I think of it, said the mother; for it stands to reason your face is dirty, Ianu, whether I can see it or not.
column3: But I make you wash it, every time I think of it, said the mother; for it stands to reason your face is dirty, Ianu, whether I can see it or not.

column2: Dorothy laughed and stretched out her hands.
column3: Dorothy laughed and stretched out her hands.

column2: Come here, please Ianu and your sister and let me feel of you, she requested.
column3: Come here, please Ianu and your sister and let me feel of you, she requested.

column2: They came to her willingly, and Dorothy passed her hands over their faces and forms and decided one was a girl of about her own age and the other a boy somewhat smaller.
column3: They came to her willingly, and Dorothy passed her hands over their faces and forms and decided one was a girl of about her own age and the other a boy somewhat smaller.

column2: The girl's hair was soft and fluffy and her skin as smooth as satin. When Dorothy gently touched her nose and ears and lips they seemed to be well and delicately formed.
column3: The girl's hair was soft and fluffy and her skin as smooth as satin. When Dorothy gently touched her nose and ears and lips they seemed to be well and delicately formed.

column2: If I could see you I am sure you would be beautiful, she declared.
column3: If I could see you I am sure you would be beautiful, she declared.

column2: The girl laughed, and her mother said:
column3: The girl laughed, and her mother said:

column2: We are not vain in the Valley of Voe, because we can not display our beauty, and good actions and pleasant ways are what make us lovely to our companions.
column3: We are not vain in the Valley of Voe, because we can not display our beauty, and good actions and pleasant ways are what make us lovely to our companions.

column2: Yet we can see and appreciate the beauties of nature, the dainty flowers and trees, the green fields and the clear blue of the sky.
column3: Yet we can see and appreciate the beauties of nature, the dainty flowers and trees, the green fields and the clear blue of the sky.

column2: How about the birds and beasts and fishes? asked Zeb.
column3: How about the birds and beasts and fishes? asked Zeb.

column2: The birds we cannot see, because they love to eat of the damas as much as we do; yet we hear their sweet songs and enjoy them.
column3: The birds we cannot see, because they love to eat of the damas as much as we do; yet we hear their sweet songs and enjoy them.

column2: Neither can we see the cruel bears, for they also eat the fruit. But the fishes that swim in our brooks we can see, and often we catch them to eat.
column3: Neither can we see the cruel bears, for they also eat the fruit. But the fishes that swim in our brooks we can see, and often we catch them to eat.

column2: It occurs to me you have a great deal to make you happy, even while invisible, remarked the Wizard. Nevertheless, we prefer to remain visible while we are in your valley.
column3: It occurs to me you have a great deal to make you happy, even while invisible, remarked the Wizard. Nevertheless, we prefer to remain visible while we are in your valley.

column2: Just then Eureka came in, for she had been until now wandering outside with Jim; and when the kitten saw the table set with food she cried out:
column3: Just then Eureka came in, for she had been until now wandering outside with Jim; and when the kitten saw the table set with food she cried out:

column2: Now you must feed me, Dorothy, for I'm half starved.
column3: Now you must feed me, Dorothy, for I'm half starved.

column2: The children were inclined to be frightened by the sight of the small animal, which reminded them of the bears; but Dorothy reassured them by explaining that Eureka was a pet and could do no harm even if she wished to.
column3: The children were inclined to be frightened by the sight of the small animal, which reminded them of the bears; but Dorothy reassured them by explaining that Eureka was a pet and could do no harm even if she wished to.

column2: Then, as the others had by this time moved away from the table, the kitten sprang upon the chair and put her paws upon the cloth to see what there was to eat.
column3: Then, as the others had by this time moved away from the table, the kitten sprang upon the chair and put her paws upon the cloth to see what there was to eat.

column2: To her surprise an unseen hand clutched her and held her suspended in the air. Eureka was frantic with terror, and tried to scratch and bite,
column3: To her surprise an unseen hand clutched her and held her suspended in the air. Eureka was frantic with terror, and tried to scratch and bite,

column2: so the next moment she was dropped to the floor.
column3: so the next moment she was dropped to the floor.

column2: Did you see that, Dorothy? she gasped.
column3: Did you see that, Dorothy? she gasped.

column2: Yes, dear, her mistress replied; there are people living in this house, although we cannot see them. And you must have better manners, Eureka,
column3: Yes, dear, her mistress replied; there are people living in this house, although we cannot see them. And you must have better manners, Eureka,

column2: or something worse will happen to you.
column3: or something worse will happen to you.

column2: She placed a plate of food upon the floor and the kitten ate greedily.
column3: She placed a plate of food upon the floor and the kitten ate greedily.

column2: Give me that nice-smelling fruit I saw on the table, she begged, when she had cleaned the plate.
column3: Give me that nice-smelling fruit I saw on the table, she begged, when she had cleaned the plate.

column2: Those are damas, said Dorothy, and you must never even taste them, Eureka, or you'll get invis'ble, and then we can't see you at all.
column3: Those are damas, said Dorothy, and you must never even taste them, Eureka, or you'll get invis'ble, and then we can't see you at all.

column2: The kitten gazed wistfully at the forbidden fruit.
column3: The kitten gazed wistfully at the forbidden fruit.

column2: Does it hurt to be invis'ble? she asked.
column3: Does it hurt to be invis'ble? she asked.

column2: I don't know, Dorothy answered; but it would hurt me dre'fully to lose you.
column3: I don't know, Dorothy answered; but it would hurt me dre'fully to lose you.

column2: Very well, I won't touch it, decided the kitten; but you must keep it away from me, for the smell is very tempting.
column3: Very well, I won't touch it, decided the kitten; but you must keep it away from me, for the smell is very tempting.

column2: Can you tell us, sir or ma'am, said the Wizard, addressing the air because he did not quite know where the unseen people stood, if there is any way we can get out of your beautiful Valley,
column3: Can you tell us, sir or ma'am, said the Wizard, addressing the air because he did not quite know where the unseen people stood, if there is any way we can get out of your beautiful Valley,

column2: and on top of the Earth again.
column3: and on top of the Earth again.

column2: Oh, one can leave the Valley easily enough, answered the man's voice; but to do so you must enter a far less pleasant country.
column3: Oh, one can leave the Valley easily enough, answered the man's voice; but to do so you must enter a far less pleasant country.

column2: As for reaching the top of the earth, I have never heard that it is possible to do that, and if you succeeded in getting there you would probably fall off.
column3: As for reaching the top of the earth, I have never heard that it is possible to do that, and if you succeeded in getting there you would probably fall off.

column2: Oh, no, said Dorothy, we've been there, and we know.
column3: Oh, no, said Dorothy, we've been there, and we know.

column2: The Valley of Voe is certainly a charming place, resumed the Wizard; but we cannot be contented in any other land than our own, for long.
column3: The Valley of Voe is certainly a charming place, resumed the Wizard; but we cannot be contented in any other land than our own, for long.

column2: Even if we should come to unpleasant places on our way it is necessary, in order to reach the earth's surface, to keep moving on toward it.
column3: Even if we should come to unpleasant places on our way it is necessary, in order to reach the earth's surface, to keep moving on toward it.

column2: In that case, said the man, it will be best for you to cross our Valley and mount the spiral staircase inside the Pyramid Mountain.
column3: In that case, said the man, it will be best for you to cross our Valley and mount the spiral staircase inside the Pyramid Mountain.

column2: The top of that mountain is lost in the clouds, and when you reach it you will be in the awful Land of Naught, where the Gargoyles live.
column3: The top of that mountain is lost in the clouds, and when you reach it you will be in the awful Land of Naught, where the Gargoyles live.

column2: What are Gargoyles? asked Zeb.
column3: What are Gargoyles? asked Zeb.

column2: I do not know, young sir. Our greatest Champion, Overman-Anu, once climbed the spiral stairway and fought nine days with the Gargoyles before he could escape them and come back;
column3: I do not know, young sir. Our greatest Champion, Overman-Anu, once climbed the spiral stairway and fought nine days with the Gargoyles before he could escape them and come back;

column2: but he could never be induced to describe the dreadful creatures, and soon afterward a bear caught him and ate him up.
column3: but he could never be induced to describe the dreadful creatures, and soon afterward a bear caught him and ate him up.

column2: The wanders were rather discouraged by this gloomy report, but Dorothy said with a sigh:
column3: The wanders were rather discouraged by this gloomy report, but Dorothy said with a sigh:

column2: If the only way to get home is to meet the Gurgles, then we've got to meet 'em. They can't be worse than the Wicked Witch or the Nome King.
column3: If the only way to get home is to meet the Gurgles, then we've got to meet 'em. They can't be worse than the Wicked Witch or the Nome King.

column2: But you must remember you had the Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman to help you conquer those enemies, suggested the Wizard. Just now, my dear, there is not a single warrior in your company.
column3: But you must remember you had the Scarecrow and the Tin Woodman to help you conquer those enemies, suggested the Wizard. Just now, my dear, there is not a single warrior in your company.

column2: Oh, I guess Zeb could fight if he had to. Couldn't you, Zeb? asked the little girl.
column3: Oh, I guess Zeb could fight if he had to. Couldn't you, Zeb? asked the little girl.

column2: Perhaps; if I had to, answered Zeb, doubtfully.
column3: Perhaps; if I had to, answered Zeb, doubtfully.

column2: And you have the jointed sword that you chopped the veg'table Sorcerer in two with, the girl said to the little man.
column3: And you have the jointed sword that you chopped the veg'table Sorcerer in two with, the girl said to the little man.

column2: True, he replied; and in my satchel are other useful things to fight with.
column3: True, he replied; and in my satchel are other useful things to fight with.

column2: What the Gargoyles most dread is a noise, said the man's voice. Our Champion told me that when he shouted his battle-cry the creatures shuddered and drew back,
column3: What the Gargoyles most dread is a noise, said the man's voice. Our Champion told me that when he shouted his battle-cry the creatures shuddered and drew back,

column2: hesitating to continue the combat.
column3: hesitating to continue the combat.

column2: But they were in great numbers, and the Champion could not shout much because he had to save his breath for fighting.
column3: But they were in great numbers, and the Champion could not shout much because he had to save his breath for fighting.

column2: Very good, said the Wizard; we can all yell better than we can fight, so we ought to defeat the Gargoyles.
column3: Very good, said the Wizard; we can all yell better than we can fight, so we ought to defeat the Gargoyles.

column2: But tell me, said Dorothy, how did such a brave Champion happen to let the bears eat him? And if he was invis'ble, and the bears invis'ble, who knows that they really ate him up?
column3: But tell me, said Dorothy, how did such a brave Champion happen to let the bears eat him? And if he was invis'ble, and the bears invis'ble, who knows that they really ate him up?

column2: The Champion had killed eleven bears in his time, returned the unseen man; and we know this is true because when any creature is dead the invisible charm of the dama-fruit ceases to be active,
column3: The Champion had killed eleven bears in his time, returned the unseen man; and we know this is true because when any creature is dead the invisible charm of the dama-fruit ceases to be active,

column2: and the slain one can be plainly seen by all eyes.
column3: and the slain one can be plainly seen by all eyes.

column2: When the Champion killed a bear everyone could see it; and when the bears killed the Champion we all saw several pieces of him scattered about,
column3: When the Champion killed a bear everyone could see it; and when the bears killed the Champion we all saw several pieces of him scattered about,

column2: which of course disappeared again when the bears devoured them.
column3: which of course disappeared again when the bears devoured them.

column2: They now bade farewell to the kind but unseen people of the cottage, and after the man had called their attention to a high, pyramid-shaped mountain on the opposite side of the Valley,
column3: They now bade farewell to the kind but unseen people of the cottage, and after the man had called their attention to a high, pyramid-shaped mountain on the opposite side of the Valley,

column2: and told them how to travel in order to reach it, they again started upon their journey.
column3: and told them how to travel in order to reach it, they again started upon their journey.

column2: They followed the course of a broad stream and passed several more pretty cottages; but of course they saw no one, nor did any one speak to them.
column3: They followed the course of a broad stream and passed several more pretty cottages; but of course they saw no one, nor did any one speak to them.

column2: Fruits and flowers grew plentifully all about, and there were many of the delicious damas that the people of Voe were so fond of.
column3: Fruits and flowers grew plentifully all about, and there were many of the delicious damas that the people of Voe were so fond of.

column2: About noon they stopped to allow Jim to rest in the shade of a pretty orchard, and while they plucked and ate some of the cherries and plums that grew there a soft voice suddenly said to them:
column3: About noon they stopped to allow Jim to rest in the shade of a pretty orchard, and while they plucked and ate some of the cherries and plums that grew there a soft voice suddenly said to them:

column2: There are bears near by. Be careful.
column3: There are bears near by. Be careful.

column2: The Wizard got out his sword at once, and Zeb grabbed the horse-whip.
column3: The Wizard got out his sword at once, and Zeb grabbed the horse-whip.

column2: Dorothy climbed into the buggy, although Jim had been unharnessed from it and was grazing some distance away.
column3: Dorothy climbed into the buggy, although Jim had been unharnessed from it and was grazing some distance away.

column2: The owner of the unseen voice laughed lightly and said:
column3: The owner of the unseen voice laughed lightly and said:

column2: You cannot escape the bears that way.
column3: You cannot escape the bears that way.

column2: How CAN we 'scape? asked Dorothy, nervously, for an unseen danger is always the hardest to face.
column3: How CAN we 'scape? asked Dorothy, nervously, for an unseen danger is always the hardest to face.

column2: You must take to the river, was the reply. The bears will not venture upon the water.
column3: You must take to the river, was the reply. The bears will not venture upon the water.

column2: But we would be drowned! exclaimed the girl.
column3: But we would be drowned! exclaimed the girl.

column2: Oh, there is no need of that, said the voice, which from its gentle tones seemed to belong to a young girl. You are strangers in the Valley of Voe,
column3: Oh, there is no need of that, said the voice, which from its gentle tones seemed to belong to a young girl. You are strangers in the Valley of Voe,

column2: and do not seem to know our ways; so I will try to save you.
column3: and do not seem to know our ways; so I will try to save you.

column2: The next moment a broad-leaved plant was jerked from the ground where it grew and held suspended in the air before the Wizard.
column3: The next moment a broad-leaved plant was jerked from the ground where it grew and held suspended in the air before the Wizard.

column2: Sir, said the voice, you must rub these leaves upon the soles of all your feet, and then you will be able to walk upon the water without sinking below the surface.
column3: Sir, said the voice, you must rub these leaves upon the soles of all your feet, and then you will be able to walk upon the water without sinking below the surface.

column2: It is a secret the bears do not know, and we people of Voe usually walk upon the water when we travel, and so escape our enemies.
column3: It is a secret the bears do not know, and we people of Voe usually walk upon the water when we travel, and so escape our enemies.

column2: Thank you! cried the Wizard, joyfully, and at once rubbed a leaf upon the soles of Dorothy's shoes and then upon his own.
column3: Thank you! cried the Wizard, joyfully, and at once rubbed a leaf upon the soles of Dorothy's shoes and then upon his own.

column2: The girl took a leaf and rubbed it upon the kitten's paws, and the rest of the plant was handed to Zeb, who, after applying it to his own feet,
column3: The girl took a leaf and rubbed it upon the kitten's paws, and the rest of the plant was handed to Zeb, who, after applying it to his own feet,

column2: carefully rubbed it upon all four of Jim's hoofs and then upon the tires of the buggy-wheels.
column3: carefully rubbed it upon all four of Jim's hoofs and then upon the tires of the buggy-wheels.

column2: He had nearly finished this last task when a low growling was suddenly heard and the horse began to jump around and kick viciously with his heels.
column3: He had nearly finished this last task when a low growling was suddenly heard and the horse began to jump around and kick viciously with his heels.

column2: Quick! To the water or you are lost! cried their unseen friend, and without hesitation the Wizard drew the buggy down the bank and out upon the broad river,
column3: Quick! To the water or you are lost! cried their unseen friend, and without hesitation the Wizard drew the buggy down the bank and out upon the broad river,

column2: for Dorothy was still seated in it with Eureka in her arms.
column3: for Dorothy was still seated in it with Eureka in her arms.

column2: They did not sink at all, owing to the virtues of the strange plant they had used, and when the buggy was in the middle of the stream the Wizard returned to the bank to assist Zeb and Jim.
column3: They did not sink at all, owing to the virtues of the strange plant they had used, and when the buggy was in the middle of the stream the Wizard returned to the bank to assist Zeb and Jim.

column2: The horse was plunging madly about, and two or three deep gashes appeared upon its flanks, from which the blood flowed freely.
column3: The horse was plunging madly about, and two or three deep gashes appeared upon its flanks, from which the blood flowed freely.

column2: Run for the river! shouted the Wizard, and Jim quickly freed himself from his unseen tormenters by a few vicious kicks and then obeyed.
column3: Run for the river! shouted the Wizard, and Jim quickly freed himself from his unseen tormenters by a few vicious kicks and then obeyed.

column2: As soon as he trotted out upon the surface of the river he found himself safe from pursuit, and Zeb was already running across the water toward Dorothy.
column3: As soon as he trotted out upon the surface of the river he found himself safe from pursuit, and Zeb was already running across the water toward Dorothy.

column2: As the little Wizard turned to follow them he felt a hot breath against his cheek and heard a low, fierce growl. At once he began stabbing at the air with his sword,
column3: As the little Wizard turned to follow them he felt a hot breath against his cheek and heard a low, fierce growl. At once he began stabbing at the air with his sword,

column3: The third time that he thrust out the weapon there was a loud roar and a fall, and suddenly at his feet appeared the form of a great red bear,

column2: which was nearly as big as the horse and much stronger and fiercer.
column3: which was nearly as big as the horse and much stronger and fiercer.

column2: for other menacing growls told him more bears were near.

column2: On the river, however, the adventurers seemed to be perfectly safe.

column2: Dorothy and the buggy had floated slowly down stream with the current of the water, and the others made haste to join her.
column3: Dorothy and the buggy had floated slowly down stream with the current of the water, and the others made haste to join her.

column3: The Wizard opened his satchel and got out some sticking-plaster with which he mended the cuts Jim had received from the claws of the bears.

column2: I think we'd better stick to the river, after this, said Dorothy.
column3: I think we'd better stick to the river, after this, said Dorothy.

column2: If our unknown friend hadn't warned us, and told us what to do, we would all be dead by this time.
column3: If our unknown friend hadn't warned us, and told us what to do, we would all be dead by this time.

column2: That is true, agreed the Wizard, and as the river seems to be flowing in the direction of the Pyramid Mountain it will be the easiest way for us to travel.
column3: That is true, agreed the Wizard, and as the river seems to be flowing in the direction of the Pyramid Mountain it will be the easiest way for us to travel.

column2: Zeb hitched Jim to the buggy again, and the horse trotted along and drew them rapidly over the smooth water. The kitten was at first dreadfully afraid of getting wet,
column3: Zeb hitched Jim to the buggy again, and the horse trotted along and drew them rapidly over the smooth water. The kitten was at first dreadfully afraid of getting wet,

column2: but Dorothy let her down and soon Eureka was frisking along beside the buggy without being scared a bit.
column3: but Dorothy let her down and soon Eureka was frisking along beside the buggy without being scared a bit.

column2: Once a little fish swam too near the surface, and the kitten grabbed it in her mouth and ate it up as quick as a wink; but Dorothy cautioned her to be careful what she ate in this valley of enchantments,
column3: Once a little fish swam too near the surface, and the kitten grabbed it in her mouth and ate it up as quick as a wink; but Dorothy cautioned her to be careful what she ate in this valley of enchantments,

column2: and no more fishes were careless enough to swim within reach.
column3: and no more fishes were careless enough to swim within reach.

column2: After a journey of several hours they came to a point where the river curved, and they found they must cross a mile or so of the Valley before they came to the Pyramid Mountain.
column3: After a journey of several hours they came to a point where the river curved, and they found they must cross a mile or so of the Valley before they came to the Pyramid Mountain.

column2: There were few houses in this part, and few orchards or flowers; so our friends feared they might encounter more of the savage bears, which they had learned to dread with all their hearts.
column3: There were few houses in this part, and few orchards or flowers; so our friends feared they might encounter more of the savage bears, which they had learned to dread with all their hearts.

column2: You'll have to make a dash, Jim, said the Wizard, and run as fast as you can go.
column3: You'll have to make a dash, Jim, said the Wizard, and run as fast as you can go.

column2: All right, answered the horse; I'll do my best. But you must remember I'm old, and my dashing days are past and gone.
column3: All right, answered the horse; I'll do my best. But you must remember I'm old, and my dashing days are past and gone.

column2: All three got into the buggy and Zeb picked up the reins, though Jim needed no guidance of any sort. The horse was still smarting from the sharp claws of the invisible bears,
column3: All three got into the buggy and Zeb picked up the reins, though Jim needed no guidance of any sort. The horse was still smarting from the sharp claws of the invisible bears,

column2: and as soon as he was on land and headed toward the mountain the thought that more of those fearsome creatures might be near acted as a spur and sent him galloping along in a way that made Dorothy catch her breath.
column3: and as soon as he was on land and headed toward the mountain the thought that more of those fearsome creatures might be near acted as a spur and sent him galloping along in a way that made Dorothy catch her breath.

column2: Then Zeb, in a spirit of mischief, uttered a growl like that of the bears, and Jim pricked up his ears and fairly flew. His boney legs moved so fast they could scarcely be seen,
column3: Then Zeb, in a spirit of mischief, uttered a growl like that of the bears, and Jim pricked up his ears and fairly flew. His boney legs moved so fast they could scarcely be seen,

column2: and the Wizard clung fast to the seat and yelled Whoa! at the top of his voice.
column3: and the Wizard clung fast to the seat and yelled Whoa! at the top of his voice.

column2: I I'm 'fraid he's he's running away! gasped Dorothy.
column3: I I'm 'fraid he's he's running away! gasped Dorothy.

column2: I KNOW he is, said Zeb; but no bear can catch him if he keeps up that gait and the harness or the buggy don't break.
column3: I KNOW he is, said Zeb; but no bear can catch him if he keeps up that gait and the harness or the buggy don't break.

column2: Jim did not make a mile a minute; but almost before they were aware of it he drew up at the foot of the mountain,
column3: Jim did not make a mile a minute; but almost before they were aware of it he drew up at the foot of the mountain,

column2: so suddenly that the Wizard and Zeb both sailed over the dashboard and landed in the soft grass where they rolled over several times before they stopped.
column3: so suddenly that the Wizard and Zeb both sailed over the dashboard and landed in the soft grass where they rolled over several times before they stopped.

column2: Dorothy nearly went with them, but she was holding fast to the iron rail of the seat, and that saved her. She squeezed the kitten, though, until it screeched;
column3: Dorothy nearly went with them, but she was holding fast to the iron rail of the seat, and that saved her. She squeezed the kitten, though, until it screeched;

column2: and then the old cab-horse made several curious sounds that led the little girl to suspect he was laughing at them all.
column3: and then the old cab-horse made several curious sounds that led the little girl to suspect he was laughing at them all.

column2: End of chapter 9.
column3: End of chapter nine.

column2: Dorothy and the Wizard in Oz L Frank Baum. Chapter 10. The Braided Man of Pyramid Mountain.
column3: Dorothy and the Wizard in Oz L Frank Baum. Chapter ten. The Braided Man of Pyramid Mountain.

column2: The mountain before them was shaped like a cone and was so tall that its point was lost in the clouds. Directly facing the place where Jim had stopped was an arched opening leading to a broad stairway.
column3: The mountain before them was shaped like a cone and was so tall that its point was lost in the clouds. Directly facing the place where Jim had stopped was an arched opening leading to a broad stairway.

column2: The stairs were cut in the rock inside the mountain, and they were broad and not very steep, because they circled around like a cork-screw, and at the arched opening where the flight began the circle was quite big.
column3: The stairs were cut in the rock inside the mountain, and they were broad and not very steep, because they circled around like a cork-screw, and at the arched opening where the flight began the circle was quite big.

column2: At the foot of the stairs was a sign reading:
column3: At the foot of the stairs was a sign reading:

column2: WARNING. These steps lead to the Land of the Gargoyles. DANGER! KEEP OUT.
column3: WARNING. These steps lead to the Land of the Gargoyles. DANGER! KEEP OUT.

column2: I wonder how Jim is ever going to draw the buggy up so many stairs, said Dorothy, gravely.
column3: I wonder how Jim is ever going to draw the buggy up so many stairs, said Dorothy, gravely.

column2: No trouble at all, declared the horse, with a contemptuous neigh.
column3: No trouble at all, declared the horse, with a contemptuous neigh.

column2: Still, I don't care to drag any passengers. You'll all have to walk.
column3: Still, I don't care to drag any passengers. You'll all have to walk.

column2: Suppose the stairs get steeper? suggested Zeb, doubtfully.
column3: Suppose the stairs get steeper? suggested Zeb, doubtfully.

column2: Then you'll have to boost the buggy-wheels, that's all, answered Jim.
column3: Then you'll have to boost the buggy-wheels, that's all, answered Jim.

column2: We'll try it, anyway, said the Wizard. It's the only way to get out of the Valley of Voe.
column3: We'll try it, anyway, said the Wizard. It's the only way to get out of the Valley of Voe.

column2: So they began to ascend the stairs, Dorothy and the Wizard first, Jim next, drawing the buggy, and then Zeb to watch that nothing happened to the harness.
column3: So they began to ascend the stairs, Dorothy and the Wizard first, Jim next, drawing the buggy, and then Zeb to watch that nothing happened to the harness.

column2: The light was dim, and soon they mounted into total darkness, so that the Wizard was obliged to get out his lanterns to light the way.
column3: The light was dim, and soon they mounted into total darkness, so that the Wizard was obliged to get out his lanterns to light the way.

column2: But this enabled them to proceed steadily until they came to a landing where there was a rift in the side of the mountain that let in both light and air.
column3: But this enabled them to proceed steadily until they came to a landing where there was a rift in the side of the mountain that let in both light and air.

column2: Looking through this opening they could see the Valley of Voe lying far below them, the cottages seeming like toy houses from that distance.
column3: Looking through this opening they could see the Valley of Voe lying far below them, the cottages seeming like toy houses from that distance.

column2: After resting a few moments they resumed their climb, and still the stairs were broad and low enough for Jim to draw the buggy easily after him.
column3: After resting a few moments they resumed their climb, and still the stairs were broad and low enough for Jim to draw the buggy easily after him.

column2: The old horse panted a little, and had to stop often to get his breath. At such times they were all glad to wait for him, for continually climbing up stairs is sure to make one's legs ache.
column3: The old horse panted a little, and had to stop often to get his breath. At such times they were all glad to wait for him, for continually climbing up stairs is sure to make one's legs ache.

column2: They wound about, always going upward, for some time. The lights from the lanterns dimly showed the way, but it was a gloomy journey,
column3: They wound about, always going upward, for some time. The lights from the lanterns dimly showed the way, but it was a gloomy journey,

column2: and they were pleased when a broad streak of light ahead assured them they were coming to a second landing.
column3: and they were pleased when a broad streak of light ahead assured them they were coming to a second landing.

column2: Here one side of the mountain had a great hole in it, like the mouth of a cavern, and the stairs stopped at the near edge of the floor and commenced ascending again at the opposite edge.
column3: Here one side of the mountain had a great hole in it, like the mouth of a cavern, and the stairs stopped at the near edge of the floor and commenced ascending again at the opposite edge.

column2: The opening in the mountain was on the side opposite to the Valley of Voe, and our travellers looked out upon a strange scene.
column3: The opening in the mountain was on the side opposite to the Valley of Voe, and our travellers looked out upon a strange scene.

column2: Below them was a vast space, at the bottom of which was a black sea with rolling billows, through which little tongues of flame constantly shot up.
column3: Below them was a vast space, at the bottom of which was a black sea with rolling billows, through which little tongues of flame constantly shot up.

column2: Just above them, and almost on a level with their platform, were banks of rolling clouds which constantly shifted position and changed color.
column3: Just above them, and almost on a level with their platform, were banks of rolling clouds which constantly shifted position and changed color.

column2: The blues and greys were very beautiful, and Dorothy noticed that on the cloud banks sat or reclined fleecy, shadowy forms of beautiful beings who must have been the Cloud Fairies.
column3: The blues and greys were very beautiful, and Dorothy noticed that on the cloud banks sat or reclined fleecy, shadowy forms of beautiful beings who must have been the Cloud Fairies.

column2: Mortals who stand upon the earth and look up at the sky cannot often distinguish these forms, but our friends were now so near to the clouds that they observed the dainty fairies very clearly.
column3: Mortals who stand upon the earth and look up at the sky cannot often distinguish these forms, but our friends were now so near to the clouds that they observed the dainty fairies very clearly.

column2: Are they real? asked Zeb, in an awed voice.
column3: Are they real? asked Zeb, in an awed voice.

column2: Of course, replied Dorothy, softly. They are the Cloud Fairies.
column3: Of course, replied Dorothy, softly. They are the Cloud Fairies.

column2: They seem like open-work, remarked the boy, gazing intently. If I should squeeze one, there wouldn't be anything left of it.
column3: They seem like open-work, remarked the boy, gazing intently. If I should squeeze one, there wouldn't be anything left of it.

column2: In the open space between the clouds and the black, bubbling sea far beneath, could be seen an occasional strange bird winging its way swiftly through the air.
column3: In the open space between the clouds and the black, bubbling sea far beneath, could be seen an occasional strange bird winging its way swiftly through the air.

column2: These birds were of enormous size, and reminded Zeb of the rocs he had read about in the Arabian Nights. They had fierce eyes and sharp talons and beaks,
column3: These birds were of enormous size, and reminded Zeb of the rocs he had read about in the Arabian Nights. They had fierce eyes and sharp talons and beaks,

column2: and the children hoped none of them would venture into the cavern.
column3: and the children hoped none of them would venture into the cavern.

column2: Well, I declare! suddenly exclaimed the little Wizard. What in the world is this?
column3: Well, I declare! suddenly exclaimed the little Wizard. What in the world is this?

column2: They turned around and found a man standing on the floor in the center of the cave, who bowed very politely when he saw he had attracted their attention.
column3: They turned around and found a man standing on the floor in the center of the cave, who bowed very politely when he saw he had attracted their attention.

column2: He was a very old man, bent nearly double; but the queerest thing about him was his white hair and beard. These were so long that they reached to his feet,
column3: He was a very old man, bent nearly double; but the queerest thing about him was his white hair and beard. These were so long that they reached to his feet,

column2: and both the hair and the beard were carefully plaited into many braids, and the end of each braid fastened with a bow of colored ribbon.
column3: and both the hair and the beard were carefully plaited into many braids, and the end of each braid fastened with a bow of colored ribbon.

column2: Where did you come from? asked Dorothy, wonderingly.
column3: Where did you come from? asked Dorothy, wonderingly.

column2: No place at all, answered the man with the braids; that is, not recently. Once I lived on top the earth, but for many years I have had my factory in this spot half way up Pyramid Mountain.
column3: No place at all, answered the man with the braids; that is, not recently. Once I lived on top the earth, but for many years I have had my factory in this spot half way up Pyramid Mountain.

column2: Are we only half way up? enquired the boy, in a discouraged tone.
column3: Are we only half way up? enquired the boy, in a discouraged tone.

column2: I believe so, my lad, replied the braided man. But as I have never been in either direction, down or up, since I arrived, I cannot be positive whether it is exactly half way or not.
column3: I believe so, my lad, replied the braided man. But as I have never been in either direction, down or up, since I arrived, I cannot be positive whether it is exactly half way or not.

column2: Have you a factory in this place? asked the Wizard, who had been examining the strange personage carefully.
column3: Have you a factory in this place? asked the Wizard, who had been examining the strange personage carefully.

column2: To be sure, said the other. I am a great inventor, you must know, and I manufacture my products in this lonely spot.
column3: To be sure, said the other. I am a great inventor, you must know, and I manufacture my products in this lonely spot.

column2: What are your products? enquired the Wizard.
column3: What are your products? enquired the Wizard.

column2: Well, I make Assorted Flutters for flags and bunting, and a superior grade of Rustles for ladies' silk gowns.
column3: Well, I make Assorted Flutters for flags and bunting, and a superior grade of Rustles for ladies' silk gowns.

column2: I thought so, said the Wizard, with a sigh. May we examine some of these articles?
column3: I thought so, said the Wizard, with a sigh. May we examine some of these articles?

column2: Yes, indeed; come into my shop, please, and the braided man turned and led the way into a smaller cave, where he evidently lived.
column3: Yes, indeed; come into my shop, please, and the braided man turned and led the way into a smaller cave, where he evidently lived.

column2: Here, on a broad shelf, were several card-board boxes of various sizes, each tied with cotton cord.
column3: Here, on a broad shelf, were several card-board boxes of various sizes, each tied with cotton cord.

column2: This, said the man, taking up a box and handling it gently, contains twelve dozen rustles enough to last any lady a year. Will you buy it, my dear? he asked, addressing Dorothy.
column3: This, said the man, taking up a box and handling it gently, contains twelve dozen rustles enough to last any lady a year. Will you buy it, my dear? he asked, addressing Dorothy.

column2: My gown isn't silk, she said, smiling.
column3: My gown isn't silk, she said, smiling.

column2: Never mind. When you open the box the rustles will escape, whether you are wearing a silk dress or not, said the man, seriously.
column3: Never mind. When you open the box the rustles will escape, whether you are wearing a silk dress or not, said the man, seriously.

column2: Then he picked up another box. In this, he continued, are many assorted flutters. They are invaluable to make flags flutter on a still day, when there is no wind.
column3: Then he picked up another box. In this, he continued, are many assorted flutters. They are invaluable to make flags flutter on a still day, when there is no wind.

column2: You, sir, turning to the Wizard, ought to have this assortment. Once you have tried my goods I am sure you will never be without them.
column3: You, sir, turning to the Wizard, ought to have this assortment. Once you have tried my goods I am sure you will never be without them.

column2: I have no money with me, said the Wizard, evasively.
column3: I have no money with me, said the Wizard, evasively.

column2: I do not want money, returned the braided man, for I could not spend it in this deserted place if I had it. But I would like very much a blue hair-ribbon.
column3: I do not want money, returned the braided man, for I could not spend it in this deserted place if I had it. But I would like very much a blue hair-ribbon.

column2: You will notice my braids are tied with yellow, pink, brown, red, green, white and black; but I have no blue ribbons.
column3: You will notice my braids are tied with yellow, pink, brown, red, green, white and black; but I have no blue ribbons.

column2: I'll get you one! cried Dorothy, who was sorry for the poor man; so she ran back to the buggy and took from her suit-case a pretty blue ribbon.
column3: I'll get you one! cried Dorothy, who was sorry for the poor man; so she ran back to the buggy and took from her suit-case a pretty blue ribbon.

column2: It did her good to see how the braided man's eyes sparkled when he received this treasure.
column3: It did her good to see how the braided man's eyes sparkled when he received this treasure.

column2: You have made me very, very happy, my dear! he exclaimed; and then he insisted on the Wizard taking the box of flutters and the little girl accepting the box of rustles.
column3: You have made me very, very happy, my dear! he exclaimed; and then he insisted on the Wizard taking the box of flutters and the little girl accepting the box of rustles.

column2: You may need them, some time, he said, and there is really no use in my manufacturing these things unless somebody uses them.
column3: You may need them, some time, he said, and there is really no use in my manufacturing these things unless somebody uses them.

column2: Why did you leave the surface of the earth? enquired the Wizard.
column3: Why did you leave the surface of the earth? enquired the Wizard.

column2: I could not help it. It is a sad story, but if you will try to restrain your tears I will tell you about it. On earth I was a manufacturer of Imported Holes for American Swiss Cheese,
column3: I could not help it. It is a sad story, but if you will try to restrain your tears I will tell you about it. On earth I was a manufacturer of Imported Holes for American Swiss Cheese,

column2: and I will acknowledge that I supplied a superior article, which was in great demand.
column3: and I will acknowledge that I supplied a superior article, which was in great demand.

column2: Also I made pores for porous plasters and high-grade holes for doughnuts and buttons. Finally I invented a new Adjustable Post-hole, which I thought would make my fortune.
column3: Also I made pores for porous plasters and high-grade holes for doughnuts and buttons. Finally I invented a new Adjustable Post-hole, which I thought would make my fortune.

column2: I manufactured a large quantity of these post-holes, and having no room in which to store them I set them all end to end and put the top one in the ground.
column3: I manufactured a large quantity of these post-holes, and having no room in which to store them I set them all end to end and put the top one in the ground.

column2: That made an extraordinary long hole, as you may imagine, and reached far down into the earth; and, as I leaned over it to try to see to the bottom,
column3: That made an extraordinary long hole, as you may imagine, and reached far down into the earth; and, as I leaned over it to try to see to the bottom,

column2: I lost my balance and tumbled in.
column3: I lost my balance and tumbled in.

column2: Unfortunately, the hole led directly into the vast space you see outside this mountain; but I managed to catch a point of rock that projected from this cavern,
column3: Unfortunately, the hole led directly into the vast space you see outside this mountain; but I managed to catch a point of rock that projected from this cavern,

column2: and so saved myself from tumbling headlong into the black waves beneath, where the tongues of flame that dart out would certainly have consumed me.
column3: and so saved myself from tumbling headlong into the black waves beneath, where the tongues of flame that dart out would certainly have consumed me.

column2: Here, then, I made my home; and although it is a lonely place I amuse myself making rustles and flutters, and so get along very nicely.
column3: Here, then, I made my home; and although it is a lonely place I amuse myself making rustles and flutters, and so get along very nicely.

column2: When the braided man had completed this strange tale Dorothy nearly laughed, because it was all so absurd; but the Wizard tapped his forehead significantly,
column3: When the braided man had completed this strange tale Dorothy nearly laughed, because it was all so absurd; but the Wizard tapped his forehead significantly,

column2: to indicate that he thought the poor man was crazy.
column3: to indicate that he thought the poor man was crazy.

column2: So they politely bade him good day, and went back to the outer cavern to resume their journey.
column3: So they politely bade him good day, and went back to the outer cavern to resume their journey.

column2: End of chapter 10.
column3: End of chapter ten.

column2: Dorothy and the Wizard in Oz L Frank Baum. Chapter 11. They Meet the Wooden Gargoyles.
column3: Dorothy and the Wizard in Oz L Frank Baum. Chapter eleven. They Meet the Wooden Gargoyles.

column2: Another breathless climb brought our adventurers to a third landing where there was a rift in the mountain. On peering out all they could see was rolling banks of clouds,
column3: Another breathless climb brought our adventurers to a third landing where there was a rift in the mountain. On peering out all they could see was rolling banks of clouds,

column2: so thick that they obscured all else.
column3: so thick that they obscured all else.

column2: But the travellers were obliged to rest, and while they were sitting on the rocky floor the Wizard felt in his pocket and brought out the nine tiny piglets.
column3: But the travellers were obliged to rest, and while they were sitting on the rocky floor the Wizard felt in his pocket and brought out the nine tiny piglets.

column2: To his delight they were now plainly visible, which proved that they had passed beyond the influence of the magical Valley of Voe.
column3: To his delight they were now plainly visible, which proved that they had passed beyond the influence of the magical Valley of Voe.

column2: Why, we can see each other again! cried one, joyfully.
column3: Why, we can see each other again! cried one, joyfully.

column2: Yes, sighed Eureka; and I also can see you again, and the sight makes me dreadfully hungry. Please, Mr. Wizard, may I eat just one of the fat little piglets?
column3: Yes, sighed Eureka; and I also can see you again, and the sight makes me dreadfully hungry. Please, Mr. Wizard, may I eat just one of the fat little piglets?

column2: You'd never miss ONE of them, I'm sure!
column3: You'd never miss ONE of them, I'm sure!

column2: What a horrid, savage beast! exclaimed a piglet; and after we've been such good friends, too, and played with one another!
column3: What a horrid, savage beast! exclaimed a piglet; and after we've been such good friends, too, and played with one another!

column2: When I'm not hungry, I love to play with you all, said the kitten, demurely; but when my stomach is empty it seems that nothing would fill it so nicely as a fat piglet.
column3: When I'm not hungry, I love to play with you all, said the kitten, demurely; but when my stomach is empty it seems that nothing would fill it so nicely as a fat piglet.

column2: And we trusted you so! said another of the nine, reproachfully.
column3: And we trusted you so! said another of the nine, reproachfully.

column2: And thought you were respectable! said another.
column3: And thought you were respectable! said another.

column2: It seems we were mistaken, declared a third, looking at the kitten timorously, no one with such murderous desires should belong to our party, I'm sure.
column3: It seems we were mistaken, declared a third, looking at the kitten timorously, no one with such murderous desires should belong to our party, I'm sure.

column2: You see, Eureka, remarked Dorothy, reprovingly, you are making yourself disliked. There are certain things proper for a kitten to eat; but I never heard of a kitten eating a pig, under ANY cir'stances.
column3: You see, Eureka, remarked Dorothy, reprovingly, you are making yourself disliked. There are certain things proper for a kitten to eat; but I never heard of a kitten eating a pig, under ANY cir'stances.

column2: Did you ever see such little pigs before? asked the kitten. They are no bigger than mice, and I'm sure mice are proper for me to eat.
column3: Did you ever see such little pigs before? asked the kitten. They are no bigger than mice, and I'm sure mice are proper for me to eat.

column2: It isn't the bigness, dear; its the variety, replied the girl.
column3: It isn't the bigness, dear; its the variety, replied the girl.

column2: These are Mr. Wizard's pets, just as you are my pet, and it wouldn't be any more proper for you to eat them than it would be for Jim to eat you.
column3: These are Mr. Wizard's pets, just as you are my pet, and it wouldn't be any more proper for you to eat them than it would be for Jim to eat you.

column2: And that's just what I shall do if you don't let those little balls of pork alone, said Jim, glaring at the kitten with his round, big eyes.
column3: And that's just what I shall do if you don't let those little balls of pork alone, said Jim, glaring at the kitten with his round, big eyes.

column2: If you injure any one of them I'll chew you up instantly.
column3: If you injure any one of them I'll chew you up instantly.

column2: The kitten looked at the horse thoughtfully, as if trying to decide whether he meant it or not.
column3: The kitten looked at the horse thoughtfully, as if trying to decide whether he meant it or not.

column2: In that case, she said, I'll leave them alone. You haven't many teeth left, Jim, but the few you have are sharp enough to make me shudder.
column3: In that case, she said, I'll leave them alone. You haven't many teeth left, Jim, but the few you have are sharp enough to make me shudder.

column2: So the piglets will be perfectly safe, hereafter, as far as I am concerned.
column3: So the piglets will be perfectly safe, hereafter, as far as I am concerned.

column2: That is right, Eureka, remarked the Wizard, earnestly. Let us all be a happy family and love one another.
column3: That is right, Eureka, remarked the Wizard, earnestly. Let us all be a happy family and love one another.

column2: Eureka yawned and stretched herself.
column3: Eureka yawned and stretched herself.

column2: I've always loved the piglets, she said; but they don't love me.
column3: I've always loved the piglets, she said; but they don't love me.

column2: No one can love a person he's afraid of, asserted Dorothy. If you behave, and don't scare the little pigs, I'm sure they'll grow very fond of you.
column3: No one can love a person he's afraid of, asserted Dorothy. If you behave, and don't scare the little pigs, I'm sure they'll grow very fond of you.

column2: The Wizard now put the nine tiny ones back into his pocket and the journey was resumed.
column3: The Wizard now put the nine tiny ones back into his pocket and the journey was resumed.

column2: We must be pretty near the top, now, said the boy, as they climbed wearily up the dark, winding stairway.
column3: We must be pretty near the top, now, said the boy, as they climbed wearily up the dark, winding stairway.

column2: The Country of the Gurgles can't be far from the top of the earth, remarked Dorothy. It isn't very nice down here. I'd like to get home again, I'm sure.
column3: The Country of the Gurgles can't be far from the top of the earth, remarked Dorothy. It isn't very nice down here. I'd like to get home again, I'm sure.

column2: No one replied to this, because they found they needed all their breath for the climb. The stairs had become narrower and Zeb and the Wizard often had to help Jim pull the buggy from one step to another,
column3: No one replied to this, because they found they needed all their breath for the climb. The stairs had become narrower and Zeb and the Wizard often had to help Jim pull the buggy from one step to another,

column2: or keep it from jamming against the rocky walls.
column3: or keep it from jamming against the rocky walls.

column2: At last, however, a dim light appeared ahead of them, which grew clearer and stronger as they advanced.
column3: At last, however, a dim light appeared ahead of them, which grew clearer and stronger as they advanced.

column2: Thank goodness we're nearly there! panted the little Wizard.
column3: Thank goodness we're nearly there! panted the little Wizard.

column2: Jim, who was in advance, saw the last stair before him and stuck his head above the rocky sides of the stairway. Then he halted, ducked down and began to back up,
column3: Jim, who was in advance, saw the last stair before him and stuck his head above the rocky sides of the stairway. Then he halted, ducked down and began to back up,

column2: so that he nearly fell with the buggy onto the others.
column3: so that he nearly fell with the buggy onto the others.

column2: Let's go down again! he said, in his hoarse voice.
column3: Let's go down again! he said, in his hoarse voice.

column2: Nonsense! snapped the tired Wizard. What's the matter with you, old man?
column3: Nonsense! snapped the tired Wizard. What's the matter with you, old man?

column2: Everything, grumbled the horse. I've taken a look at this place, and it's no fit country for real creatures to go to. Everything's dead, up there no flesh or blood or growing thing anywhere.
column3: Everything, grumbled the horse. I've taken a look at this place, and it's no fit country for real creatures to go to. Everything's dead, up there no flesh or blood or growing thing anywhere.

column2: Never mind; we can't turn back, said Dorothy; and we don't intend to stay there, anyhow.
column3: Never mind; we can't turn back, said Dorothy; and we don't intend to stay there, anyhow.

column2: It's dangerous, growled Jim, in a stubborn tone.
column3: It's dangerous, growled Jim, in a stubborn tone.

column2: See here, my good steed, broke in the Wizard, little Dorothy and I have been in many queer countries in our travels, and always escaped without harm.
column3: See here, my good steed, broke in the Wizard, little Dorothy and I have been in many queer countries in our travels, and always escaped without harm.

column2: We've even been to the marvelous Land of Oz haven't we, Dorothy? so we don't much care what the Country of the Gargoyles is like.
column3: We've even been to the marvelous Land of Oz haven't we, Dorothy? so we don't much care what the Country of the Gargoyles is like.

column2: Go ahead, Jim, and whatever happens we'll make the best of it.
column3: Go ahead, Jim, and whatever happens we'll make the best of it.

column2: All right, answered the horse; this is your excursion, and not mine; so if you get into trouble don't blame me.
column3: All right, answered the horse; this is your excursion, and not mine; so if you get into trouble don't blame me.

column2: With this speech he bent forward and dragged the buggy up the remaining steps.
column3: With this speech he bent forward and dragged the buggy up the remaining steps.

column2: The others followed and soon they were all standing upon a broad platform and gazing at the most curious and startling sight their eyes had ever beheld.
column3: The others followed and soon they were all standing upon a broad platform and gazing at the most curious and startling sight their eyes had ever beheld.

column2: The Country of the Gargoyles is all wooden! exclaimed Zeb; and so it was. The ground was sawdust and the pebbles scattered around were hard knots from trees,
column3: The Country of the Gargoyles is all wooden! exclaimed Zeb; and so it was. The ground was sawdust and the pebbles scattered around were hard knots from trees,

column2: worn smooth in course of time.
column3: worn smooth in course of time.

column2: There were odd wooden houses, with carved wooden flowers in the front yards. The tree-trunks were of coarse wood, but the leaves of the trees were shavings.
column3: There were odd wooden houses, with carved wooden flowers in the front yards. The tree-trunks were of coarse wood, but the leaves of the trees were shavings.

column2: The patches of grass were splinters of wood, and where neither grass nor sawdust showed was a solid wooden flooring. Wooden birds fluttered among the trees and wooden cows were browsing upon the wooden grass;
column3: The patches of grass were splinters of wood, and where neither grass nor sawdust showed was a solid wooden flooring. Wooden birds fluttered among the trees and wooden cows were browsing upon the wooden grass;

column2: but the most amazing things of all were the wooden people the creatures known as Gargoyles.
column3: but the most amazing things of all were the wooden people the creatures known as Gargoyles.

column2: These were very numerous, for the place was thickly inhabited, and a large group of the queer people clustered near, gazing sharply upon the strangers who had emerged from the long spiral stairway.
column3: These were very numerous, for the place was thickly inhabited, and a large group of the queer people clustered near, gazing sharply upon the strangers who had emerged from the long spiral stairway.

column2: The Gargoyles were very small of stature, being less than three feet in height. Their bodies were round, their legs short and thick and their arms extraordinarily long and stout.
column3: The Gargoyles were very small of stature, being less than three feet in height. Their bodies were round, their legs short and thick and their arms extraordinarily long and stout.

column2: Their heads were too big for their bodies and their faces were decidedly ugly to look upon. Some had long, curved noses and chins, small eyes and wide, grinning mouths.
column3: Their heads were too big for their bodies and their faces were decidedly ugly to look upon. Some had long, curved noses and chins, small eyes and wide, grinning mouths.

column2: Others had flat noses, protruding eyes, and ears that were shaped like those of an elephant. There were many types, indeed, scarcely two being alike;
column3: Others had flat noses, protruding eyes, and ears that were shaped like those of an elephant. There were many types, indeed, scarcely two being alike;

column2: but all were equally disagreeable in appearance.
column3: but all were equally disagreeable in appearance.

column2: The tops of their heads had no hair, but were carved into a variety of fantastic shapes, some having a row of points or balls around the top,
column3: The tops of their heads had no hair, but were carved into a variety of fantastic shapes, some having a row of points or balls around the top,

column2: others designs resembling flowers or vegetables, and still others having squares that looked like waffles cut criss-cross on their heads.
column3: others designs resembling flowers or vegetables, and still others having squares that looked like waffles cut criss-cross on their heads.

column2: They all wore short wooden wings which were fastened to their wooden bodies by means of wooden hinges with wooden screws, and with these wings they flew swiftly and noiselessly here and there,
column3: They all wore short wooden wings which were fastened to their wooden bodies by means of wooden hinges with wooden screws, and with these wings they flew swiftly and noiselessly here and there,

column2: their legs being of little use to them.
column3: their legs being of little use to them.

column2: This noiseless motion was one of the most peculiar things about the Gargoyles. They made no sounds at all, either in flying or trying to speak,
column3: This noiseless motion was one of the most peculiar things about the Gargoyles. They made no sounds at all, either in flying or trying to speak,

column2: and they conversed mainly by means of quick signals made with their wooden fingers or lips.
column3: and they conversed mainly by means of quick signals made with their wooden fingers or lips.

column2: Neither was there any sound to be heard anywhere throughout the wooden country. The birds did not sing, nor did the cows moo; yet there was more than ordinary activity everywhere.
column3: Neither was there any sound to be heard anywhere throughout the wooden country. The birds did not sing, nor did the cows moo; yet there was more than ordinary activity everywhere.

column2: The group of these queer creatures which was discovered clustered near the stairs at first remained staring and motionless, glaring with evil eyes at the intruders who had so suddenly appeared in their land.
column3: The group of these queer creatures which was discovered clustered near the stairs at first remained staring and motionless, glaring with evil eyes at the intruders who had so suddenly appeared in their land.

column2: In turn the Wizard and the children, the horse and the kitten, examined the Gargoyles with the same silent attention.
column3: In turn the Wizard and the children, the horse and the kitten, examined the Gargoyles with the same silent attention.

column2: There's going to be trouble, I'm sure, remarked the horse. Unhitch those tugs, Zeb, and set me free from the buggy, so I can fight comfortably.
column3: There's going to be trouble, I'm sure, remarked the horse. Unhitch those tugs, Zeb, and set me free from the buggy, so I can fight comfortably.

column2: Jim's right, sighed the Wizard. There's going to be trouble, and my sword isn't stout enough to cut up those wooden bodies so I shall have to get out my revolvers.
column3: Jim's right, sighed the Wizard. There's going to be trouble, and my sword isn't stout enough to cut up those wooden bodies so I shall have to get out my revolvers.

column2: He got his satchel from the buggy and, opening it, took out two deadly looking revolvers that made the children shrink back in alarm just to look at.
column3: He got his satchel from the buggy and, opening it, took out two deadly looking revolvers that made the children shrink back in alarm just to look at.

column2: What harm can the Gurgles do? asked Dorothy. They have no weapons to hurt us with.
column3: What harm can the Gurgles do? asked Dorothy. They have no weapons to hurt us with.

column2: Each of their arms is a wooden club, answered the little man, and I'm sure the creatures mean mischief, by the looks of their eyes.
column3: Each of their arms is a wooden club, answered the little man, and I'm sure the creatures mean mischief, by the looks of their eyes.

column2: Even these revolvers can merely succeed in damaging a few of their wooden bodies, and after that we will be at their mercy.
column3: Even these revolvers can merely succeed in damaging a few of their wooden bodies, and after that we will be at their mercy.

column2: But why fight at all, in that case? asked the girl.
column3: But why fight at all, in that case? asked the girl.

column2: So I may die with a clear conscience, returned the Wizard, gravely.
column3: So I may die with a clear conscience, returned the Wizard, gravely.

column2: It's every man's duty to do the best he knows how; and I'm going to do it.
column3: It's every man's duty to do the best he knows how; and I'm going to do it.

column2: Wish I had an axe, said Zeb, who by now had unhitched the horse.
column3: Wish I had an axe, said Zeb, who by now had unhitched the horse.

column2: If we had known we were coming we might have brought along several other useful things, responded the Wizard. But we dropped into this adventure rather unexpectedly.
column3: If we had known we were coming we might have brought along several other useful things, responded the Wizard. But we dropped into this adventure rather unexpectedly.

column2: The Gargoyles had backed away a distance when they heard the sound of talking, for although our friends had spoken in low tones their words seemed loud in the silence surrounding them.
column3: The Gargoyles had backed away a distance when they heard the sound of talking, for although our friends had spoken in low tones their words seemed loud in the silence surrounding them.

column2: But as soon as the conversation ceased, the grinning, ugly creatures arose in a flock and flew swiftly toward the strangers, their long arms stretched out before them like the bowsprits of a fleet of sail-boats.
column3: But as soon as the conversation ceased, the grinning, ugly creatures arose in a flock and flew swiftly toward the strangers, their long arms stretched out before them like the bowsprits of a fleet of sail-boats.

column2: The horse had especially attracted their notice, because it was the biggest and strangest creature they had ever seen; so it became the center of their first attack.
column3: The horse had especially attracted their notice, because it was the biggest and strangest creature they had ever seen; so it became the center of their first attack.

column2: But Jim was ready for them, and when he saw them coming he turned his heels toward them and began kicking out as hard as he could. Crack!
column3: But Jim was ready for them, and when he saw them coming he turned his heels toward them and began kicking out as hard as he could. Crack!

column2: crash! bang! went his iron-shod hoofs against the wooden bodies of the Gargoyles, and they were battered right and left with such force that they scattered like straws in the wind.
column3: crash! bang! went his iron-shod hoofs against the wooden bodies of the Gargoyles, and they were battered right and left with such force that they scattered like straws in the wind.

column2: But the noise and clatter seemed as dreadful to them as Jim's heels, for all who were able swiftly turned and flew away to a great distance.
column3: But the noise and clatter seemed as dreadful to them as Jim's heels, for all who were able swiftly turned and flew away to a great distance.

column2: The others picked themselves up from the ground one by one and quickly rejoined their fellows, so for a moment the horse thought he had won the fight with ease.
column3: The others picked themselves up from the ground one by one and quickly rejoined their fellows, so for a moment the horse thought he had won the fight with ease.

column2: But the Wizard was not so confident.
column3: But the Wizard was not so confident.

column2: Those wooden things are impossible to hurt, he said, and all the damage Jim has done to them is to knock a few splinters from their noses and ears.
column3: Those wooden things are impossible to hurt, he said, and all the damage Jim has done to them is to knock a few splinters from their noses and ears.

column2: That cannot make them look any uglier, I'm sure, and it is my opinion they will soon renew the attack.
column3: That cannot make them look any uglier, I'm sure, and it is my opinion they will soon renew the attack.

column2: What made them fly away? asked Dorothy.
column3: What made them fly away? asked Dorothy.

column2: The noise, of course. Don't you remember how the Champion escaped them by shouting his battle-cry?
column3: The noise, of course. Don't you remember how the Champion escaped them by shouting his battle-cry?

column2: Suppose we escape down the stairs, too, suggested the boy. We have time, just now, and I'd rather face the invis'ble bears than those wooden imps.
column3: Suppose we escape down the stairs, too, suggested the boy. We have time, just now, and I'd rather face the invis'ble bears than those wooden imps.

column2: No, returned Dorothy, stoutly, it won't do to go back, for then we would never get home. Let's fight it out.
column3: No, returned Dorothy, stoutly, it won't do to go back, for then we would never get home. Let's fight it out.

column2: That is what I advise, said the Wizard. They haven't defeated us yet, and Jim is worth a whole army.
column3: That is what I advise, said the Wizard. They haven't defeated us yet, and Jim is worth a whole army.

column2: But the Gargoyles were clever enough not to attack the horse the next time. They advanced in a great swarm, having been joined by many more of their kind,
column3: But the Gargoyles were clever enough not to attack the horse the next time. They advanced in a great swarm, having been joined by many more of their kind,

column2: and they flew straight over Jim's head to where the others were standing.
column3: and they flew straight over Jim's head to where the others were standing.

column2: The Wizard raised one of his revolvers and fired into the throng of his enemies, and the shot resounded like a clap of thunder in that silent place.
column3: The Wizard raised one of his revolvers and fired into the throng of his enemies, and the shot resounded like a clap of thunder in that silent place.

column2: Some of the wooden beings fell flat upon the ground, where they quivered and trembled in every limb; but most of them managed to wheel and escape again to a distance.
column3: Some of the wooden beings fell flat upon the ground, where they quivered and trembled in every limb; but most of them managed to wheel and escape again to a distance.

column2: Zeb ran and picked up one of the Gargoyles that lay nearest to him.
column3: Zeb ran and picked up one of the Gargoyles that lay nearest to him.

column2: The top of its head was carved into a crown and the Wizard's bullet had struck it exactly in the left eye, which was a hard wooden knot.
column3: The top of its head was carved into a crown and the Wizard's bullet had struck it exactly in the left eye, which was a hard wooden knot.

column2: Half of the bullet stuck in the wood and half stuck out, so it had been the jar and the sudden noise that had knocked the creature down, more than the fact that it was really hurt.
column3: Half of the bullet stuck in the wood and half stuck out, so it had been the jar and the sudden noise that had knocked the creature down, more than the fact that it was really hurt.

column2: Before this crowned Gargoyle had recovered himself Zeb had wound a strap several times around its body, confining its wings and arms so that it could not move.
column3: Before this crowned Gargoyle had recovered himself Zeb had wound a strap several times around its body, confining its wings and arms so that it could not move.

column2: Then, having tied the wooden creature securely, the boy buckled the strap and tossed his prisoner into the buggy. By that time the others had all retired.
column3: Then, having tied the wooden creature securely, the boy buckled the strap and tossed his prisoner into the buggy. By that time the others had all retired.

column2: End of chapter 11.
