column2: Dorothy and the Wizard in Oz L Frank Baum. Chapter 12. A Wonderful Escape.
column3: Dorothy and the Wizard in Oz L Frank Baum. Chapter twelve. A Wonderful Escape.

column2: For a while the enemy hesitated to renew the attack. Then a few of them advanced until another shot from the Wizard's revolver made them retreat.
column3: For a while the enemy hesitated to renew the attack. Then a few of them advanced until another shot from the Wizard's revolver made them retreat.

column2: That's fine, said Zeb. We've got 'em on the run now, sure enough.
column3: That's fine, said Zeb. We've got 'em on the run now, sure enough.

column2: But only for a time, replied the Wizard, shaking his head gloomily.
column3: But only for a time, replied the Wizard, shaking his head gloomily.

column2: These revolvers are good for six shots each, but when those are gone we shall be helpless.
column3: These revolvers are good for six shots each, but when those are gone we shall be helpless.

column2: The Gargoyles seemed to realize this, for they sent a few of their band time after time to attack the strangers and draw the fire from the little man's revolvers.
column3: The Gargoyles seemed to realize this, for they sent a few of their band time after time to attack the strangers and draw the fire from the little man's revolvers.

column2: In this way none of them was shocked by the dreadful report more than once, for the main band kept far away and each time a new company was sent into the battle.
column3: In this way none of them was shocked by the dreadful report more than once, for the main band kept far away and each time a new company was sent into the battle.

column2: When the Wizard had fired all of his twelve bullets he had caused no damage to the enemy except to stun a few by the noise, and so be as no nearer to victory than in the beginning of the fray.
column3: When the Wizard had fired all of his twelve bullets he had caused no damage to the enemy except to stun a few by the noise, and so be as no nearer to victory than in the beginning of the fray.

column2: What shall we do now? asked Dorothy, anxiously.
column3: What shall we do now? asked Dorothy, anxiously.

column2: Let's yell all together, said Zeb.
column3: Let's yell all together, said Zeb.

column2: And fight at the same time, added the Wizard. We will get near Jim, so that he can help us, and each one must take some weapon and do the best he can.
column3: And fight at the same time, added the Wizard. We will get near Jim, so that he can help us, and each one must take some weapon and do the best he can.

column2: I'll use my sword, although it isn't much account in this affair. Dorothy must take her parasol and open it suddenly when the wooden folks attack her.
column3: I'll use my sword, although it isn't much account in this affair. Dorothy must take her parasol and open it suddenly when the wooden folks attack her.

column2: I haven't anything for you, Zeb.
column3: I haven't anything for you, Zeb.

column2: I'll use the king, said the boy, and pulled his prisoner out of the buggy. The bound Gargoyle's arms extended far out beyond its head, so by grasping its wrists Zeb found the king made a very good club.
column3: I'll use the king, said the boy, and pulled his prisoner out of the buggy. The bound Gargoyle's arms extended far out beyond its head, so by grasping its wrists Zeb found the king made a very good club.

column2: The boy was strong for one of his years, having always worked upon a farm; so he was likely to prove more dangerous to the enemy than the Wizard.
column3: The boy was strong for one of his years, having always worked upon a farm; so he was likely to prove more dangerous to the enemy than the Wizard.

column2: When the next company of Gargoyles advanced, our adventurers began yelling as if they had gone mad. Even the kitten gave a dreadfully shrill scream and at the same time Jim the cab-horse neighed loudly.
column3: When the next company of Gargoyles advanced, our adventurers began yelling as if they had gone mad. Even the kitten gave a dreadfully shrill scream and at the same time Jim the cab-horse neighed loudly.

column2: This daunted the enemy for a time, but the defenders were soon out of breath. Perceiving this, as well as the fact that there were no more of the awful bangs to come from the revolvers,
column3: This daunted the enemy for a time, but the defenders were soon out of breath. Perceiving this, as well as the fact that there were no more of the awful bangs to come from the revolvers,

column2: the Gargoyles advanced in a swarm as thick as bees, so that the air was filled with them.
column3: the Gargoyles advanced in a swarm as thick as bees, so that the air was filled with them.

column2: Dorothy squatted upon the ground and put up her parasol, which nearly covered her and proved a great protection.
column3: Dorothy squatted upon the ground and put up her parasol, which nearly covered her and proved a great protection.

column2: The Wizard's sword-blade snapped into a dozen pieces at the first blow he struck against the wooden people.
column3: The Wizard's sword-blade snapped into a dozen pieces at the first blow he struck against the wooden people.

column2: Zeb pounded away with the Gargoyle he was using as a club until he had knocked down dozens of foes; but at the last they clustered so thickly about him that he no longer had room in which to swing his arms.
column3: Zeb pounded away with the Gargoyle he was using as a club until he had knocked down dozens of foes; but at the last they clustered so thickly about him that he no longer had room in which to swing his arms.

column2: The horse performed some wonderful kicking and even Eureka assisted when she leaped bodily upon the Gargoyles and scratched and bit at them like a wild-cat.
column3: The horse performed some wonderful kicking and even Eureka assisted when she leaped bodily upon the Gargoyles and scratched and bit at them like a wild-cat.

column2: But all this bravery amounted to nothing at all. The wooden things wound their long arms around Zeb and the Wizard and held them fast.
column3: But all this bravery amounted to nothing at all. The wooden things wound their long arms around Zeb and the Wizard and held them fast.

column2: Dorothy was captured in the same way, and numbers of the Gargoyles clung to Jim's legs, so weighting him down that the poor beast was helpless.
column3: Dorothy was captured in the same way, and numbers of the Gargoyles clung to Jim's legs, so weighting him down that the poor beast was helpless.

column2: Eureka made a desperate dash to escape and scampered along the ground like a streak; but a grinning Gargoyle flew after her and grabbed her before she had gone very far.
column3: Eureka made a desperate dash to escape and scampered along the ground like a streak; but a grinning Gargoyle flew after her and grabbed her before she had gone very far.

column2: All of them expected nothing less than instant death; but to their surprise the wooden creatures flew into the air with them and bore them far away,
column3: All of them expected nothing less than instant death; but to their surprise the wooden creatures flew into the air with them and bore them far away,

column2: over miles and miles of wooden country, until they came to a wooden city.
column3: over miles and miles of wooden country, until they came to a wooden city.

column2: The houses of this city had many corners, being square and six-sided and eight-sided. They were tower-like in shape and the best of them seemed old and weather-worn;
column3: The houses of this city had many corners, being square and six-sided and eight-sided. They were tower-like in shape and the best of them seemed old and weather-worn;

column2: yet all were strong and substantial.
column3: yet all were strong and substantial.

column2: To one of these houses which had neither doors nor windows, but only one broad opening far up underneath the roof, the prisoners were brought by their captors.
column3: To one of these houses which had neither doors nor windows, but only one broad opening far up underneath the roof, the prisoners were brought by their captors.

column2: The Gargoyles roughly pushed them into the opening, where there was a platform, and then flew away and left them.
column3: The Gargoyles roughly pushed them into the opening, where there was a platform, and then flew away and left them.

column2: As they had no wings the strangers could not fly away, and if they jumped down from such a height they would surely be killed.
column3: As they had no wings the strangers could not fly away, and if they jumped down from such a height they would surely be killed.

column2: The creatures had sense enough to reason that way, and the only mistake they made was in supposing the earth people were unable to overcome such ordinary difficulties.
column3: The creatures had sense enough to reason that way, and the only mistake they made was in supposing the earth people were unable to overcome such ordinary difficulties.

column2: Jim was brought with the others, although it took a good many Gargoyles to carry the big beast through the air and land him on the high platform,
column3: Jim was brought with the others, although it took a good many Gargoyles to carry the big beast through the air and land him on the high platform,

column2: and the buggy was thrust in after him because it belonged to the party and the wooden folks had no idea what it was used for or whether it was alive or not.
column3: and the buggy was thrust in after him because it belonged to the party and the wooden folks had no idea what it was used for or whether it was alive or not.

column2: When Eureka's captor had thrown the kitten after the others the last Gargoyle silently disappeared, leaving our friends to breathe freely once more.
column3: When Eureka's captor had thrown the kitten after the others the last Gargoyle silently disappeared, leaving our friends to breathe freely once more.

column2: What an awful fight! said Dorothy, catching her breath in little gasps.
column3: What an awful fight! said Dorothy, catching her breath in little gasps.

column2: Oh, I don't know, purred Eureka, smoothing her ruffled fur with her paw; we didn't manage to hurt anybody, and nobody managed to hurt us.
column3: Oh, I don't know, purred Eureka, smoothing her ruffled fur with her paw; we didn't manage to hurt anybody, and nobody managed to hurt us.

column2: Thank goodness we are together again, even if we are prisoners, sighed the little girl.
column3: Thank goodness we are together again, even if we are prisoners, sighed the little girl.

column2: I wonder why they didn't kill us on the spot, remarked Zeb, who had lost his king in the struggle.
column3: I wonder why they didn't kill us on the spot, remarked Zeb, who had lost his king in the struggle.

column2: They are probably keeping us for some ceremony, the Wizard answered, reflectively; but there is no doubt they intend to kill us as dead as possible in a short time.
column3: They are probably keeping us for some ceremony, the Wizard answered, reflectively; but there is no doubt they intend to kill us as dead as possible in a short time.

column2: As dead as poss'ble would be pretty dead, wouldn't it? asked Dorothy.
column3: As dead as poss'ble would be pretty dead, wouldn't it? asked Dorothy.

column2: Yes, my dear. But we have no need to worry about that just now. Let us examine our prison and see what it is like.
column3: Yes, my dear. But we have no need to worry about that just now. Let us examine our prison and see what it is like.

column2: The space underneath the roof, where they stood, permitted them to see on all sides of the tall building, and they looked with much curiosity at the city spread out beneath them.
column3: The space underneath the roof, where they stood, permitted them to see on all sides of the tall building, and they looked with much curiosity at the city spread out beneath them.

column2: Everything visible was made of wood, and the scene seemed stiff and extremely unnatural.
column3: Everything visible was made of wood, and the scene seemed stiff and extremely unnatural.

column2: From their platform a stair descended into the house, and the children and the Wizard explored it after lighting a lantern to show them the way.
column3: From their platform a stair descended into the house, and the children and the Wizard explored it after lighting a lantern to show them the way.

column2: Several stories of empty rooms rewarded their search, but nothing more; so after a time they came back to the platform again.
column3: Several stories of empty rooms rewarded their search, but nothing more; so after a time they came back to the platform again.

column2: Had there been any doors or windows in the lower rooms, or had not the boards of the house been so thick and stout, escape could have been easy;
column3: Had there been any doors or windows in the lower rooms, or had not the boards of the house been so thick and stout, escape could have been easy;

column2: but to remain down below was like being in a cellar or the hold of a ship, and they did not like the darkness or the damp smell.
column3: but to remain down below was like being in a cellar or the hold of a ship, and they did not like the darkness or the damp smell.

column2: In this country, as in all others they had visited underneath the earth's surface, there was no night, a constant and strong light coming from some unknown source.
column3: In this country, as in all others they had visited underneath the earth's surface, there was no night, a constant and strong light coming from some unknown source.

column2: Looking out, they could see into some of the houses near them, where there were open windows in abundance, and were able to mark the forms of the wooden Gargoyles moving about in their dwellings.
column3: Looking out, they could see into some of the houses near them, where there were open windows in abundance, and were able to mark the forms of the wooden Gargoyles moving about in their dwellings.

column2: This seems to be their time of rest, observed the Wizard. All people need rest, even if they are made of wood, and as there is no night here they select a certain time of the day in which to sleep or doze.
column3: This seems to be their time of rest, observed the Wizard. All people need rest, even if they are made of wood, and as there is no night here they select a certain time of the day in which to sleep or doze.

column2: I feel sleepy myself, remarked Zeb, yawning.
column3: I feel sleepy myself, remarked Zeb, yawning.

column2: Why, where's Eureka? cried Dorothy, suddenly.
column3: Why, where's Eureka? cried Dorothy, suddenly.

column2: They all looked around, but the kitten was no place to be seen.
column3: They all looked around, but the kitten was no place to be seen.

column2: She's gone out for a walk, said Jim, gruffly.
column3: She's gone out for a walk, said Jim, gruffly.

column2: Where? On the roof? asked the girl.

column2: How old are you? enquired Zeb, who stared at the yellow eyes as if fascinated.
column3: How old are you? enquired Zeb, who stared at the yellow eyes as if fascinated.

column2: Quite young, I grieve to say; and all of my brothers and sisters that you see here are practically my own age. If I remember rightly, we were sixty-six years old the day before yesterday.
column3: Quite young, I grieve to say; and all of my brothers and sisters that you see here are practically my own age. If I remember rightly, we were sixty-six years old the day before yesterday.

column2: But that isn't young! cried Dorothy, in amazement.
column3: But that isn't young! cried Dorothy, in amazement.

column2: No? drawled the dragonette; it seems to me very babyish.
column3: No? drawled the dragonette; it seems to me very babyish.

column2: How old is your mother? asked the girl.
column3: How old is your mother? asked the girl.

column2: Mother's about two thousand years old; but she carelessly lost track of her age a few centuries ago and skipped several hundreds.
column3: Mother's about two thousand years old; but she carelessly lost track of her age a few centuries ago and skipped several hundreds.

column2: She's a little fussy, you know, and afraid of growing old, being a widow and still in her prime.
column3: She's a little fussy, you know, and afraid of growing old, being a widow and still in her prime.

column2: I should think she would be, agreed Dorothy. Then, after a moment's thought, she asked: Are we friends or enemies? I mean, will you be good to us, or do you intend to eat us?
column3: I should think she would be, agreed Dorothy. Then, after a moment's thought, she asked: Are we friends or enemies? I mean, will you be good to us, or do you intend to eat us?

column2: As for that, we dragonettes would love to eat you, my child; but unfortunately mother has tied all our tails around the rocks at the back of our individual caves,
column3: As for that, we dragonettes would love to eat you, my child; but unfortunately mother has tied all our tails around the rocks at the back of our individual caves,

column2: so that we can not crawl out to get you.
column3: so that we can not crawl out to get you.

column2: If you choose to come nearer we will make a mouthful of you in a wink; but unless you do you will remain quite safe.
column3: If you choose to come nearer we will make a mouthful of you in a wink; but unless you do you will remain quite safe.

column2: There was a regretful accent in the creature's voice, and at the words all the other dragonettes sighed dismally.
column3: There was a regretful accent in the creature's voice, and at the words all the other dragonettes sighed dismally.

column2: Dorothy felt relieved. Presently she asked:
column3: Dorothy felt relieved. Presently she asked:

column2: Why did your mother tie your tails?
column3: Why did your mother tie your tails?

column2: Oh, she is sometimes gone for several weeks on her hunting trips, and if we were not tied we would crawl all over the mountain and fight with each other and get into a lot of mischief.
column3: Oh, she is sometimes gone for several weeks on her hunting trips, and if we were not tied we would crawl all over the mountain and fight with each other and get into a lot of mischief.

column2: Mother usually knows what she is about, but she made a mistake this time; for you are sure to escape us unless you come too near, and you probably won't do that.
column3: Mother usually knows what she is about, but she made a mistake this time; for you are sure to escape us unless you come too near, and you probably won't do that.

column2: No, indeed! said the little girl. We don't wish to be eaten by such awful beasts.
column3: No, indeed! said the little girl. We don't wish to be eaten by such awful beasts.

column2: Permit me to say, returned the dragonette, that you are rather impolite to call us names, knowing that we cannot resent your insults.
column3: Permit me to say, returned the dragonette, that you are rather impolite to call us names, knowing that we cannot resent your insults.

column2: We consider ourselves very beautiful in appearance, for mother has told us so, and she knows. And we are of an excellent family and have a pedigree that I challenge any humans to equal,
column3: We consider ourselves very beautiful in appearance, for mother has told us so, and she knows. And we are of an excellent family and have a pedigree that I challenge any humans to equal,

column2: as it extends back about twenty thousand years, to the time of the famous Green Dragon of Atlantis, who lived in a time when humans had not yet been created.
column3: as it extends back about twenty thousand years, to the time of the famous Green Dragon of Atlantis, who lived in a time when humans had not yet been created.

column2: Can you match that pedigree, little girl?
column3: Can you match that pedigree, little girl?

column2: Well, said Dorothy, I was born on a farm in Kansas, and I guess that's being just as 'spectable and haughty as living in a cave with your tail tied to a rock.
column3: Well, said Dorothy, I was born on a farm in Kansas, and I guess that's being just as 'spectable and haughty as living in a cave with your tail tied to a rock.

column2: If it isn't I'll have to stand it, that's all.
column3: If it isn't I'll have to stand it, that's all.

column2: Tastes differ, murmured the dragonette, slowly drooping its scaley eyelids over its yellow eyes, until they looked like half-moons.
column3: Tastes differ, murmured the dragonette, slowly drooping its scaley eyelids over its yellow eyes, until they looked like half-moons.

column2: Being reassured by the fact that the creatures could not crawl out of their rock-pockets, the children and the Wizard now took time to examine them more closely.
column3: Being reassured by the fact that the creatures could not crawl out of their rock-pockets, the children and the Wizard now took time to examine them more closely.

column2: The heads of the dragonettes were as big as barrels and covered with hard, greenish scales that glittered brightly under the light of the lanterns.
column3: The heads of the dragonettes were as big as barrels and covered with hard, greenish scales that glittered brightly under the light of the lanterns.

column2: Their front legs, which grew just back of their heads, were also strong and big; but their bodies were smaller around than their heads, and dwindled away in a long line until their tails were slim as a shoe-string.
column3: Their front legs, which grew just back of their heads, were also strong and big; but their bodies were smaller around than their heads, and dwindled away in a long line until their tails were slim as a shoe-string.

column2: Dorothy thought, if it had taken them sixty-six years to grow to this size, that it would be fully a hundred years more before they could hope to call themselves dragons,
column3: Dorothy thought, if it had taken them sixty-six years to grow to this size, that it would be fully a hundred years more before they could hope to call themselves dragons,

column2: and that seemed like a good while to wait to grow up.
column3: and that seemed like a good while to wait to grow up.

column2: It occurs to me, said the Wizard, that we ought to get out of this place before the mother dragon comes back.
column3: It occurs to me, said the Wizard, that we ought to get out of this place before the mother dragon comes back.

column2: Don't hurry, called one of the dragonettes; mother will be glad to meet you, I'm sure.
column3: Don't hurry, called one of the dragonettes; mother will be glad to meet you, I'm sure.

column2: You may be right, replied the Wizard, but we're a little particular about associating with strangers. Will you kindly tell us which way your mother went to get on top the earth?
column3: You may be right, replied the Wizard, but we're a little particular about associating with strangers. Will you kindly tell us which way your mother went to get on top the earth?

column2: That is not a fair question to ask us, declared another dragonette.
column3: That is not a fair question to ask us, declared another dragonette.

column2: For, if we told you truly, you might escape us altogether; and if we told you an untruth we would be naughty and deserve to be punished.
column3: For, if we told you truly, you might escape us altogether; and if we told you an untruth we would be naughty and deserve to be punished.

column2: Then, decided Dorothy, we must find our way out the best we can.
column3: Then, decided Dorothy, we must find our way out the best we can.

column2: They circled all around the cavern, keeping a good distance away from the blinking yellow eyes of the dragonettes, and presently discovered that there were two paths leading from the wall opposite to the place where they had entered.
column3: They circled all around the cavern, keeping a good distance away from the blinking yellow eyes of the dragonettes, and presently discovered that there were two paths leading from the wall opposite to the place where they had entered.

column2: They selected one of these at a venture and hurried along it as fast as they could go, for they had no idea when the mother dragon would be back and were very anxious not to make her acquaintance.
column3: They selected one of these at a venture and hurried along it as fast as they could go, for they had no idea when the mother dragon would be back and were very anxious not to make her acquaintance.

column2: End of chapter 13.
column3: End of chapter thirteen.

column3: This is there librivox recording. All librivox recordings are in the public domain. For more information or to volunteer please visit librivox dot org.

column2: Dorothy and the Wizard in Oz L Frank Baum. Chapter 14. Ozma Uses the Magic Belt.
column3: Dorothy and the Wizard in Oz L Frank Baum. Chapter fourteen. Ozma Uses the Magic Belt.

column2: For a considerable distance the way led straight upward in a gentle incline, and the wanderers made such good progress that they grew hopeful and eager,
column3: For a considerable distance the way led straight upward in a gentle incline, and the wanderers made such good progress that they grew hopeful and eager,

column2: thinking they might see sunshine at any minute.
column3: thinking they might see sunshine at any minute.

column2: But at length they came unexpectedly upon a huge rock that shut off the passage and blocked them from proceeding a single step farther.
column3: But at length they came unexpectedly upon a huge rock that shut off the passage and blocked them from proceeding a single step farther.

column2: This rock was separate from the rest of the mountain and was in motion, turning slowly around and around as if upon a pivot.
column3: This rock was separate from the rest of the mountain and was in motion, turning slowly around and around as if upon a pivot.

column2: When first they came to it there was a solid wall before them; but presently it revolved until there was exposed a wide, smooth path across it to the other side.
column3: When first they came to it there was a solid wall before them; but presently it revolved until there was exposed a wide, smooth path across it to the other side.

column2: This appeared so unexpectedly that they were unprepared to take advantage of it at first, and allowed the rocky wall to swing around again before they had decided to pass over.
column3: This appeared so unexpectedly that they were unprepared to take advantage of it at first, and allowed the rocky wall to swing around again before they had decided to pass over.

column2: But they knew now that there was a means of escape and so waited patiently until the path appeared for the second time.
column3: But they knew now that there was a means of escape and so waited patiently until the path appeared for the second time.

column2: The children and the Wizard rushed across the moving rock and sprang into the passage beyond, landing safely though a little out of breath.
column3: The children and the Wizard rushed across the moving rock and sprang into the passage beyond, landing safely though a little out of breath.

column2: Jim the cab-horse came last, and the rocky wall almost caught him;
column3: Jim the cab-horse came last, and the rocky wall almost caught him;

column2: for just as he leaped to the floor of the further passage the wall swung across it and a loose stone that the buggy wheels knocked against fell into the narrow crack where the rock turned, and became wedged there.
column3: for just as he leaped to the floor of the further passage the wall swung across it and a loose stone that the buggy wheels knocked against fell into the narrow crack where the rock turned, and became wedged there.

column2: They heard a crunching, grinding sound, a loud snap, and the turn-table came to a stop with its broadest surface shutting off the path from which they had come.
column3: They heard a crunching, grinding sound, a loud snap, and the turn-table came to a stop with its broadest surface shutting off the path from which they had come.

column2: Never mind, said Zeb, we don't want to get back, anyhow.
column3: Never mind, said Zeb, we don't want to get back, anyhow.

column2: I'm not so sure of that, returned Dorothy. The mother dragon may come down and catch us here.
column3: I'm not so sure of that, returned Dorothy. The mother dragon may come down and catch us here.

column2: It is possible, agreed the Wizard, if this proves to be the path she usually takes. But I have been examining this tunnel, and I do not see any signs of so large a beast having passed through it.
column3: It is possible, agreed the Wizard, if this proves to be the path she usually takes. But I have been examining this tunnel, and I do not see any signs of so large a beast having passed through it.

column2: Then we're all right, said the girl, for if the dragon went the other way she can't poss'bly get to us now.
column3: Then we're all right, said the girl, for if the dragon went the other way she can't poss'bly get to us now.

column2: Of course not, my dear. But there is another thing to consider. The mother dragon probably knows the road to the earth's surface, and if she went the other way then we have come the wrong way,
column3: Of course not, my dear. But there is another thing to consider. The mother dragon probably knows the road to the earth's surface, and if she went the other way then we have come the wrong way,

column2: said the Wizard, thoughtfully.
column3: said the Wizard, thoughtfully.

column2: Dear me! cried Dorothy. That would be unlucky, wouldn't it?
column3: Dear me! cried Dorothy. That would be unlucky, wouldn't it?

column2: Very. Unless this passage also leads to the top of the earth, said Zeb. For my part, if we manage to get out of here I'll be glad it isn't the way the dragon goes.
column3: Very. Unless this passage also leads to the top of the earth, said Zeb. For my part, if we manage to get out of here I'll be glad it isn't the way the dragon goes.

column2: So will I, returned Dorothy. It's enough to have your pedigree flung in your face by those saucy dragonettes. No one knows what the mother might do.
column3: So will I, returned Dorothy. It's enough to have your pedigree flung in your face by those saucy dragonettes. No one knows what the mother might do.

column2: They now moved on again, creeping slowly up another steep incline. The lanterns were beginning to grow dim, and the Wizard poured the remaining oil from one into the other,
column3: They now moved on again, creeping slowly up another steep incline. The lanterns were beginning to grow dim, and the Wizard poured the remaining oil from one into the other,

column2: so that the one light would last longer.
column3: so that the one light would last longer.

column2: But their journey was almost over, for in a short time they reached a small cave from which there was no further outlet.
column3: But their journey was almost over, for in a short time they reached a small cave from which there was no further outlet.

column2: They did not realize their ill fortune at first, for their hearts were gladdened by the sight of a ray of sunshine coming through a small crack in the roof of the cave, far overhead.
column3: They did not realize their ill fortune at first, for their hearts were gladdened by the sight of a ray of sunshine coming through a small crack in the roof of the cave, far overhead.

column2: That meant that their world the real world was not very far away, and that the succession of perilous adventures they had encountered had at last brought them near the earth's surface, which meant home to them.
column3: That meant that their world the real world was not very far away, and that the succession of perilous adventures they had encountered had at last brought them near the earth's surface, which meant home to them.

column2: But when the adventurers looked more carefully around them they discovered that there were in a strong prison from which there was no hope of escape.
column3: But when the adventurers looked more carefully around them they discovered that there were in a strong prison from which there was no hope of escape.

column2: But we're ALMOST on earth again, cried Dorothy, for there is the sun the most BEAU'FUL sun that shines! and she pointed eagerly at the crack in the distant roof.
column3: But we're ALMOST on earth again, cried Dorothy, for there is the sun the most BEAU'FUL sun that shines! and she pointed eagerly at the crack in the distant roof.

column2: Almost on earth isn't being there, said the kitten, in a discontented tone. It wouldn't be possible for even me to get up to that crack or through it if I got there.
column3: Almost on earth isn't being there, said the kitten, in a discontented tone. It wouldn't be possible for even me to get up to that crack or through it if I got there.

column2: It appears that the path ends here, announced the Wizard, gloomily.
column3: It appears that the path ends here, announced the Wizard, gloomily.

column2: And there is no way to go back, added Zeb, with a low whistle of perplexity.
column3: And there is no way to go back, added Zeb, with a low whistle of perplexity.

column2: I was sure it would come to this, in the end, remarked the old cab-horse. Folks don't fall into the middle of the earth and then get back again to tell of their adventures not in real life.
column3: I was sure it would come to this, in the end, remarked the old cab-horse. Folks don't fall into the middle of the earth and then get back again to tell of their adventures not in real life.

column2: And the whole thing has been unnatural because that cat and I are both able to talk your language, and to understand the words you say.
column3: And the whole thing has been unnatural because that cat and I are both able to talk your language, and to understand the words you say.

column2: And so can the nine tiny piglets, added Eureka. Don't forget them, for I may have to eat them, after all.
column3: And so can the nine tiny piglets, added Eureka. Don't forget them, for I may have to eat them, after all.

column2: I've heard animals talk before, said Dorothy, and no harm came of it.
column3: I've heard animals talk before, said Dorothy, and no harm came of it.

column2: Were you ever before shut up in a cave, far under the earth, with no way of getting out? enquired the horse, seriously.
column3: Were you ever before shut up in a cave, far under the earth, with no way of getting out? enquired the horse, seriously.

column2: No, answered Dorothy. But don't you lose heart, Jim, for I'm sure this isn't the end of our story, by any means.
column3: No, answered Dorothy. But don't you lose heart, Jim, for I'm sure this isn't the end of our story, by any means.

column2: The reference to the piglets reminded the Wizard that his pets had not enjoyed much exercise lately, and must be tired of their prison in his pocket.
column3: The reference to the piglets reminded the Wizard that his pets had not enjoyed much exercise lately, and must be tired of their prison in his pocket.

column2: So he sat down upon the floor of the cave, brought the piglets out one by one, and allowed them to run around as much as they pleased.
column3: So he sat down upon the floor of the cave, brought the piglets out one by one, and allowed them to run around as much as they pleased.

column2: My dears, he said to them, I'm afraid I've got you into a lot of trouble, and that you will never again be able to leave this gloomy cave.
column3: My dears, he said to them, I'm afraid I've got you into a lot of trouble, and that you will never again be able to leave this gloomy cave.

column2: What's wrong? asked a piglet. We've been in the dark quite a while, and you may as well explain what has happened.
column3: What's wrong? asked a piglet. We've been in the dark quite a while, and you may as well explain what has happened.

column2: The Wizard told them of the misfortune that had overtaken the wanderers.
column3: The Wizard told them of the misfortune that had overtaken the wanderers.

column2: Well, said another piglet, you are a wizard, are you not?
column3: Well, said another piglet, you are a wizard, are you not?

column2: I am, replied the little man.
column3: I am, replied the little man.

column2: Then you can do a few wizzes and get us out of this hole, declared the tiny one, with much confidence.
column3: Then you can do a few wizzes and get us out of this hole, declared the tiny one, with much confidence.

column2: I could if I happened to be a real wizard, returned the master sadly.
column3: I could if I happened to be a real wizard, returned the master sadly.

column2: But I'm not, my piggy-wees; I'm a humbug wizard.
column3: But I'm not, my piggy-wees; I'm a humbug wizard.

column2: Nonsense! cried several of the piglets, together.
column3: Nonsense! cried several of the piglets, together.

column2: You can ask Dorothy, said the little man, in an injured tone.
column3: You can ask Dorothy, said the little man, in an injured tone.

column2: It's true enough, returned the girl, earnestly. Our friend Oz is merely a humbug wizard, for he once proved it to me. He can do several very wonderful things if he knows how.
column3: It's true enough, returned the girl, earnestly. Our friend Oz is merely a humbug wizard, for he once proved it to me. He can do several very wonderful things if he knows how.

column2: But he can't wiz a single thing if he hasn't the tools and machinery to work with.
column3: But he can't wiz a single thing if he hasn't the tools and machinery to work with.

column2: Thank you, my dear, for doing me justice, responded the Wizard, gratefully. To be accused of being a real wizard, when I'm not, is a slander I will not tamely submit to.
column3: Thank you, my dear, for doing me justice, responded the Wizard, gratefully. To be accused of being a real wizard, when I'm not, is a slander I will not tamely submit to.

column2: But I am one of the greatest humbug wizards that ever lived, and you will realize this when we have all starved together and our bones are scattered over the floor of this lonely cave.
column3: But I am one of the greatest humbug wizards that ever lived, and you will realize this when we have all starved together and our bones are scattered over the floor of this lonely cave.

column2: I don't believe we'll realize anything, when it comes to that, remarked Dorothy, who had been deep in thought. But I'm not going to scatter my bones just yet,
column3: I don't believe we'll realize anything, when it comes to that, remarked Dorothy, who had been deep in thought. But I'm not going to scatter my bones just yet,

column2: because I need them, and you prob'ly need yours, too.
column3: because I need them, and you prob'ly need yours, too.

column2: We are helpless to escape, sighed the Wizard.
column3: We are helpless to escape, sighed the Wizard.

column2: WE may be helpless, answered Dorothy, smiling at him, but there are others who can do more than we can. Cheer up, friends. I'm sure Ozma will help us.
column3: WE may be helpless, answered Dorothy, smiling at him, but there are others who can do more than we can. Cheer up, friends. I'm sure Ozma will help us.

column2: Ozma! exclaimed the Wizard. Who is Ozma?
column3: Ozma! exclaimed the Wizard. Who is Ozma?

column2: The girl that rules the marvelous Land of Oz, was the reply. She's a friend of mine, for I met her in the Land of Ev, not long ago, and went to Oz with her.
column3: The girl that rules the marvelous Land of Oz, was the reply. She's a friend of mine, for I met her in the Land of Ev, not long ago, and went to Oz with her.

column2: For the second time? asked the Wizard, with great interest.
column3: For the second time? asked the Wizard, with great interest.

column2: Yes. The first time I went to Oz I found you there, ruling the Emerald City. After you went up in a balloon, and escaped us, I got back to Kansas by means of a pair of magical silver shoes.
column3: Yes. The first time I went to Oz I found you there, ruling the Emerald City. After you went up in a balloon, and escaped us, I got back to Kansas by means of a pair of magical silver shoes.

column2: I remember those shoes, said the little man, nodding. They once belonged to the Wicked Witch. Have you them here with you?
column3: I remember those shoes, said the little man, nodding. They once belonged to the Wicked Witch. Have you them here with you?

column2: No; I lost them somewhere in the air, explained the child. But the second time I went to the Land of Oz I owned the Nome King's Magic Belt, which is much more powerful than were the Silver Shoes.
column3: No; I lost them somewhere in the air, explained the child. But the second time I went to the Land of Oz I owned the Nome King's Magic Belt, which is much more powerful than were the Silver Shoes.

column2: Where is that Magic Belt? enquired the Wizard, who had listened with great interest.
column3: Where is that Magic Belt? enquired the Wizard, who had listened with great interest.

column2: Ozma has it; for its powers won't work in a common, ordinary country like the United States. Anyone in a fairy country like the Land of Oz can do anything with it;
column3: Ozma has it; for its powers won't work in a common, ordinary country like the United States. Anyone in a fairy country like the Land of Oz can do anything with it;

column2: so I left it with my friend the Princess Ozma, who used it to wish me in Australia with Uncle Henry.
column3: so I left it with my friend the Princess Ozma, who used it to wish me in Australia with Uncle Henry.

column2: And were you? asked Zeb, astonished at what he heard.
column3: And were you? asked Zeb, astonished at what he heard.

column2: Of course; in just a jiffy. And Ozma has an enchanted picture hanging in her room that shows her the exact scene where any of her friends may be, at any time she chooses.
column3: Of course; in just a jiffy. And Ozma has an enchanted picture hanging in her room that shows her the exact scene where any of her friends may be, at any time she chooses.

column2: All she has to do is to say: 'I wonder what So-and-so is doing,' and at once the picture shows where her friend is and what the friend is doing.
column3: All she has to do is to say: 'I wonder what So-and-so is doing,' and at once the picture shows where her friend is and what the friend is doing.

column2: That's REAL magic, Mr. Wizard; isn't it? Well, every day at four o'clock Ozma has promised to look at me in that picture,
column3: That's REAL magic, Mr. Wizard; isn't it? Well, every day at four o'clock Ozma has promised to look at me in that picture,

column2: and if I am in need of help I am to make her a certain sign and she will put on the Nome King's Magic Belt and wish me to be with her in Oz.
column3: and if I am in need of help I am to make her a certain sign and she will put on the Nome King's Magic Belt and wish me to be with her in Oz.

column2: Do you mean that Princess Ozma will see this cave in her enchanted picture, and see all of us here, and what we are doing? demanded Zeb.
column3: Do you mean that Princess Ozma will see this cave in her enchanted picture, and see all of us here, and what we are doing? demanded Zeb.

column2: Of course; when it is four o'clock, she replied, with a laugh at his startled expression.
column3: Of course; when it is four o'clock, she replied, with a laugh at his startled expression.

column2: And when you make a sign she will bring you to her in the Land of Oz?
column3: And when you make a sign she will bring you to her in the Land of Oz?

column2: continued the boy.
column3: continued the boy.

column2: That's it, exactly; by means of the Magic Belt.
column3: That's it, exactly; by means of the Magic Belt.

column2: Then, said the Wizard, you will be saved, little Dorothy; and I am very glad of it. The rest of us will die much more cheerfully when we know you have escaped our sad fate.
column3: Then, said the Wizard, you will be saved, little Dorothy; and I am very glad of it. The rest of us will die much more cheerfully when we know you have escaped our sad fate.

column2: I won't die cheerfully! protested the kitten. There's nothing cheerful about dying that I could ever see, although they say a cat has nine lives, and so must die nine times.
column3: I won't die cheerfully! protested the kitten. There's nothing cheerful about dying that I could ever see, although they say a cat has nine lives, and so must die nine times.

column2: Have you ever died yet? enquired the boy.
column3: Have you ever died yet? enquired the boy.

column2: No, and I'm not anxious to begin, said Eureka.
column3: No, and I'm not anxious to begin, said Eureka.

column2: Don't worry, dear, Dorothy exclaimed, I'll hold you in my arms, and take you with me.
column3: Don't worry, dear, Dorothy exclaimed, I'll hold you in my arms, and take you with me.

column2: Take us, too! cried the nine tiny piglets, all in one breath.
column3: Take us, too! cried the nine tiny piglets, all in one breath.

column2: Perhaps I can, answered Dorothy. I'll try.
column3: Perhaps I can, answered Dorothy. I'll try.

column2: Couldn't you manage to hold me in your arms? asked the cab-horse.
column3: Couldn't you manage to hold me in your arms? asked the cab-horse.

column2: Dorothy laughed.
column3: Dorothy laughed.

column2: I'll do better than that, she promised, for I can easily save you all, once I am myself in the Land of Oz.
column3: I'll do better than that, she promised, for I can easily save you all, once I am myself in the Land of Oz.

column2: How? they asked.
column3: How? they asked.

column2: By using the Magic Belt. All I need do is to wish you with me, and there you'll be safe in the royal palace!
column3: By using the Magic Belt. All I need do is to wish you with me, and there you'll be safe in the royal palace!

column2: Good! cried Zeb.

column3: Jim accepted it as a mere detail, and at his command the attendants gave his coat a good rubbing, combed his mane and tail, and washed his hoofs and fetlocks.

column2: Fish! cried Jim, with a sniff. Do you take me for a tom-cat? Away with it!

column3: Well, well! said the horse, now thoroughly provoked. Do you take me for a weasel? How stupid and ignorant you are, in the Land of Oz, and what dreadful things you feed upon!

column2: Is there nothing that is decent to eat in this palace?

column2: What would your Highness like for dinner?

column2: Highness! repeated Jim, who was unused to such titles.
column3: Highness! repeated Jim, who was unused to such titles.

column3: You are at least six feet high, and that is higher than any other animal in this country, said the Steward.

column2: Well, my Highness would like some oats, declared the horse.
column3: Well, my Highness would like some oats, declared the horse.

column2: Oats? We have no whole oats, the Steward replied, with much deference. But there is any quantity of oatmeal, which we often cook for breakfast.
column3: Oats? We have no whole oats, the Steward replied, with much deference. But there is any quantity of oatmeal, which we often cook for breakfast.

column2: Oatmeal is a breakfast dish, added the Steward, humbly.
column3: Oatmeal is a breakfast dish, added the Steward, humbly.

column3: I'll make it a dinner dish, said Jim. Fetch it on, but don't cook it, as you value your life.

column3: Jim's eyes stuck out as much as those of the Sawhorse, and he stared at the creature with his ears erect and his long head drawn back until it rested against his arched neck.

column2: For goodness sake, what sort of a being are you?
column3: For goodness sake, what sort of a being are you?

column2: I'm a Sawhorse, replied the other.
column3: I'm a Sawhorse, replied the other.

column3: Oh; I believe I've heard of you, said the cab-horse; but you are unlike anything that I expected to see.

column2: I do not doubt it, the Sawhorse observed, with a tone of pride. I am considered quite unusual.
column3: I do not doubt it, the Sawhorse observed, with a tone of pride. I am considered quite unusual.

column3: You are, indeed. But a rickety wooden thing like you has no right to be alive.

column3: I couldn't help it, returned the other, rather crestfallen. Ozma sprinkled me with a magic powder, and I just had to live.

column2: I know I'm not much account; but I'm the only horse in all the Land of Oz, so they treat me with great respect.
column3: I know I'm not much account; but I'm the only horse in all the Land of Oz, so they treat me with great respect.

column2: You, a horse!
column3: You, a horse!

column2: Oh, not a real one, of course. There are no real horses here at all.
column3: Oh, not a real one, of course. There are no real horses here at all.

column2: But I'm a splendid imitation of one.

column2: Look at me! he cried. Behold a real horse!

column3: The wooden animal gave a start, and then examined the other intently.

column2: Is it possible that you are a Real Horse? he murmured.
column3: Is it possible that you are a Real Horse? he murmured.

column2: Not only possible, but true, replied Jim, who was gratified by the impression he had created. It is proved by my fine points.
column3: Not only possible, but true, replied Jim, who was gratified by the impression he had created. It is proved by my fine points.

column2: The flies never trouble me, said the Saw-Horse.
column3: The flies never trouble me, said the Saw-Horse.

column3: And notice my great strong teeth, with which I nibble the grass.

column3: It is not necessary for me to eat, observed the Sawhorse.

column3: Also examine my broad chest, which enables me to draw deep, full breaths, said Jim, proudly.

column2: I have no need to breathe, returned the other.
column3: I have no need to breathe, returned the other.

column2: nor the satisfaction of drawing a long breath of fresh, pure air.

column2: You may be an imitation of a horse, but you're a mighty poor one.
column3: You may be an imitation of a horse, but you're a mighty poor one.

column2: Oh, I cannot hope ever to be like you, sighed the Sawhorse. But I am glad to meet a last a Real Horse. You are certainly the most beautiful creature I ever beheld.
column3: Oh, I cannot hope ever to be like you, sighed the Sawhorse. But I am glad to meet a last a Real Horse. You are certainly the most beautiful creature I ever beheld.

column2: This praise won Jim completely. To be called beautiful was a novelty in his experience. Said he:
column3: This praise won Jim completely. To be called beautiful was a novelty in his experience. Said he:

column2: Your chief fault, my friend, is in being made of wood, and that I suppose you cannot help. Real horses, like myself, are made of flesh and blood and bones.
column3: Your chief fault, my friend, is in being made of wood, and that I suppose you cannot help. Real horses, like myself, are made of flesh and blood and bones.

column2: I can see the bones all right, replied the Sawhorse, and they are admirable and distinct. Also I can see the flesh. But the blood, I suppose is tucked away inside.
column3: I can see the bones all right, replied the Sawhorse, and they are admirable and distinct. Also I can see the flesh. But the blood, I suppose is tucked away inside.

column2: Exactly, said Jim.

column2: Jim did not know, but he would not tell the Sawhorse that.

column3: Please go to my boudoir, Jellia, and get the white piglet I left on the dressing-table. I want to play with it.

column3: Jellia at once departed on the errand, and she was gone so long that they had almost forgotten her mission when the green robed maiden returned with a troubled face.

column2: There is little doubt that my pretty piglet has been eaten by that horrid kitten, and if that is true the offender must be punished.

column2: Under the bed in your own room, was the reply.

column2: What shall we do now? asked the Scarecrow, with a sigh, for such a crime had cast a gloom over all the company.

column2: I will summon the Court to meet in the Throne Room at three o'clock, replied Ozma. I myself will be the judge, and the kitten shall have a fair trial.
column3: I will summon the Court to meet in the Throne Room at three o'clock, replied Ozma. I myself will be the judge, and the kitten shall have a fair trial.

column2: What will happen if she is guilty? asked Dorothy.
column3: What will happen if she is guilty? asked Dorothy.

column3: She must die, answered the Princess.

column2: Nine times? enquired the Scarecrow.
column3: Nine times? enquired the Scarecrow.

column2: As many times as is necessary, was the reply. I will ask the Tin Woodman to defend the prisoner, because he has such a kind heart I am sure he will do his best to save her.

column3: Princess Ozma, dressed in her most splendid robes of state, sat in the magnificent emerald throne, with her jewelled sceptre in her hand and her sparkling coronet upon her fair brow.

column3: the small cat you see a prisoner before you is accused of the crime of first murdering and then eating our esteemed Ruler's fat piglet or else first eating and then murdering it.

column3: Don't interrupt, little girl, said the Woggle-Bug. When I get my thoughts arranged in good order I do not like to have anything upset them or throw them into confusion.
